4 Website Tasks You Should Outsource to Robots

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n12/23/13 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Every web team is strapped for time, but most have no idea how much time they waste doing things manually when automated options are readily available. Here are four ways you’re wasting time maintaining your organization’s website.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Santa Isn't Real: 4 Common Website Redesign Myths

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n12/12/13 9:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Website redesigns tend to be treated as a magic cure for a poor web presence by many digital marketers today. Unfortunately for them, separating fact from fiction can be a sobering wake up call. Here are the top 4 myths surrounding website redesign projects today:

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

5 Reasons You Should Care About Website Errors You're Not Responsible For

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n12/10/13 9:42 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

If an issue on your organization’s website doesn't fall under your area of responsibility, then it’s not your problem, right? Not so fast. Being part of a successful web team means ensuring the entire site is cohesive and error free. That means setting aside the mindset of “not my area, not my fault” and working with your teammates. Because guess what? A problem you pretend not to notice might just land in your lap later on. Here’s why you should care about mistakes in someone else’s jurisdiction. 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

Why You Might Want To Rethink That Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n1/6/15 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Redesigning your website and expecting all of your problems to disappear is like buying a new house because you’re too lazy to clean the one you live in now. Oh, it'll look nice for a while, but eventually you’ll be up to your armpits in clutter again. The same goes for your website. Slapping on a fresh coat of paint might make it look shiny and sleek, but the fundamental problems will remain below the surface.

\n

Spending time, money, and energy on driving traffic to a broken website is a massive waste of resources. Users might be flooding your site, but if all they find are broken links, poor navigation, a lack of direction, and accessibility issues, the frustrating experience will turn them off for good.

\n

The good news? These are all issues that can be addressed on your existing site. So, what can you do instead?

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Step 1: Write Well. Step 2: Be Successful.

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/16/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The written word has been the cornerstone of human communication since roughly 3,000 B.C. I might be a little biased here, but even as we’ve moved from stone, to pen, to the ever-present keyboard, how you write is more important than ever. The Internet demands good writing. In the Digital Age, your audience’s first interaction with you/your company is often with the words you’ve written. Websites, blogs, social media, email; it’s all vying for the attention of an audience with debilitating A.D.D., and the organizations that prioritize the quality of their web content are the ones who will rise to the top.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Producing High-Quality Web Content: A Guided Tour

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/9/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

If you're one of those people who can just wake up in the morning, pour yourself a cup of your preferred breakfast-time libation, and start pounding away at your keyboard until something great comes out, we’re officially fighting and I’d like you to leave now.

\n

OK, good. They’re gone.

\n

For us common-folk, creating great content takes time, and it doesn’t happen in a vacuum. It requires a team-effort, as you’ll need input from subject matter experts and buy-in from your co-workers/bosses in order to turn a slab of rock into a piece of chiseled marble.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to be Agile in a Rigid System with Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/2/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

No organization is perfect. Big or small, B2B or B2C, every company faces challenges when it comes to managing their online presence. Resources are scarce, money is tight, and office politics might make you feel like you’re playing the Game of Thrones. You need help to address these issues and find a solution that gets results.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Increase Conversions with Proper Web Design

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/25/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Conversions are measurable actions that users complete on your website, things like: completed purchases, form submissions, button clicks, video views, document downloads, or specific page views. Every website exists (hopefully) with a specific goal or purpose, and while the types of conversions may vary between different organizations, they all share the same desire to provide their audience with a solution to their needs.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Can SEO Benefit Brick & Mortar Banks?

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/18/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Online banking is awesome. Everyone knows that. Checking balances, paying bills, transferring money, even depositing checks; online banking has made it easy for people to manage their basic finances from the comfort of their home computer or mobile device.

\n

But what about more complicated financial activities like applying for home and auto loans, planning for retirement, savings investments, or managing small business expenses? The average person will have questions. They’ll need information on how to start planning and who to trust with their money. And where does the average person begin their search for answers? That’s right, online.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Redesign Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/11/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website redesign. Those two simple words are enough to make even the most seasoned of marketers break out into a cold sweat. Research, planning, meetings, debates, design, user experience, content, development, approvals, and that’s just the process for deciding whether or not you should do a redesign. The sheer amount of work needed to pull off a website redesign is often all it takes to make companies reconsider the whole idea, but it doesn’t have to be.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Involving People With Disabilities In Your Web Project

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n11/4/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Involving people with disabilities on your web projects may seem like an overwhelming task, but if you do, it will be well worth your effort. The benefits will far outweigh the extra work, as you'll be gaining a much deeper understanding of how users with disabilities are motivated, how efficient your site may be, and how effectively all of your users can be while using your site.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Content, Your Audience, and Search Engines

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/28/14 10:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Quality over quantity, right? “But wait”, you say. “I thought that adding more content and blogs would help boost my site’s SEO rankings?” Well, yes and no. Simply cramming your website full of unfocused, aimless ramblings is actually a sure fire way to earn the ire of both your readers and that company whose name rhymes with “Moogle”. It’s Google. I’m talking about Google.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Watch Out, Australia. Here Comes Kelsey.

\n

\nPosted by\nKelsey Johnson\n

\n

\n10/14/14 5:30 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Well, I’m headed down under, to Oz, Aussie, or whatever you prefer to call it – Let me try that again… I’m going to Australia!

\n

Over the past year I’ve had the immense pleasure of working with the Oceania region, and it’s about time that I dropped in for a visit! I’ve been fortunate to build a great network of customers, influencers, and web experts across Australia that I cannot wait to meet with and discuss how Siteimprove can continue to support the needs of web teams around the world, and more specifically, in Australia.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689839080:\n\n\n\n\n\nThe 'Publication' Component of Content Strategy Success\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nThe 'Publication' Component of Content Strategy Success\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n4/22/13 4:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Having your content published was once difficult, yet with the emergence of the new media age entry requirements have almost all but disappeared. Instead, the internet has made it possible for almost everyone to share their content, but this isn’t without risks.

\n
\n
\n

With the increasing digitization of the business world, it has now become essential for organizations to become publishers in order to compete against competitors, and gain attention from their target audiences. Yet haphazard publishing can be dangerous for an organization's reputation, especially if standards of reliability, accountability, accuracy and trust slip.

\n

 

\n

Content Safeguarding is Essential

\n

The publication stage can often seem like the simplest stage of the content strategy lifecycle, yet it is also the time when credibility and reputation threats are at their highest. Therefore, it’s essential that organizations undertake two reviews, the initial and the comprehensive. An ideal way to streamline these processes with the use of cleverly simple web management tools.

\n

The Initial Review

\n

This stage should determine the overall quality of information and from a content strategy perspective should involve ensuring that published content will be compliant with international web standards. With estimates that 20% of the population has some form of disability that makes accessing the web difficult, it is essential that your site that is accessible to all. This may seem like a monster task, but with help from the Siteimprove Accessibility tool it needn’t be.  

\n

Easy to use, with helpful instruction materials, its ‘summary’ feature provides a clear overview of all accessibility issues affecting your site, as well as highlighting which errors most require your attention. By reviewing your contents accessibility, you’ll be sure to have content that is more inclusive, will better fulfill all users’ expectations, and that can even assist in improving your SEO efforts.    

\n

\n

 

\n

The Comprehensive Review

\n

An in-depth and informational review will help ensure the accuracy and completeness of information. This should involve checking to make sure that there’s no spelling mistakes anywhere on your site, that all links work as intended, and that every piece of content is where it should be. With Siteimprove Quality Assurance ensuring your website’s credibility is protected needn’t be a logistical nightmare.

\n

 

\n

Finding every single spelling mistake on your website is like finding a needle in a haystack, especially if your site has many pages, or is in more than one language. Siteimprove Quality Assurance is designed to help make this task manageable, with it’s extensive dictionary that’ll find all misspellings, and a clever editing feature that can both allow certain words, and flag those others that are deemed inappropriate.

\n

 

\n

Intuitive crawlers are also an essential part of this tool, as they check every link on every single page of your site so you don't have to. As part of this review process, our tools can also help you ensure all site content, such as email addresses, telephone numbers, videos and PDFs, is correct and where it needs to be.

\n

While the publishing stage has the potential to derail your larger content strategy it can be made much easier with the use of web management tools, and as such any organization attempting to enforce or renew their strategy should consider these options.

\n

Stay tuned for next week’ final installment in the Siteimprove Content Strategy Blog Series as we discuss tips and tricks for successful content governance.  

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

How to Stop Putting Out Fires and be Proactive With Your Website

\n
\n

BY Dave Schneider

\n

8. Apr 2014

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Everyone knows reactive marketing is ineffective, but far too many marketers are buried deep under a pile of emergencies to even think about strategic planning. What do you do when your boss comes to your desk every day to light your hair on fire with another emergency?

\n
\n

Stop Dropping and Rolling

\n

The first step is often the hardest, and this is no exception: if you want to be proactive you absolutely, positively have to stop putting out fires.

\n

I know, I know.  This isn’t a novel suggestion you’ve never thought of before, it’s probably the first thing you’d wish for if you stumbled upon a magic lamp.  Here’s another thing you probably already know: There’s a good chance the only way you’ll ever be able to do it is by taking a stand with your boss and asking him/her to hold off on bringing you little details like they’re emergencies.

\n

If you can’t get a moment’s peace to plan ahead, you’ll be stuck fighting fires for the rest of your life. That’s bad for you and bad for your organization, because you’re way less effective at doing the things they’ve hired you to do when you’re running around with your hair on fire.

\n

There are lots of great articles on the web about how to approach your boss, so I won’t go into too much detail on the specifics of how to do it. Make sure you have a private discussion with your boss about how to reach a mutual goal, instead of confronting them in a meeting. Plan what you’re going to say ahead of time, and make sure you speak in terms that matter to them, keeping the company as the focus. How much more of the company’s objectives could you accomplish if you weren’t constantly putting out fires? How can you work together to lessen the flow of emergencies to make that happen?

\n

It’s a scary conversation to initiate, but if you want to be proactive it’s 100% necessary.

\n

Make Yourself Flame Retardant

\n

Now that you’ve talked to your boss and reached an agreement on stopping or slowing the fires, it’s time to start working ahead. If you don’t have written goals and objectives for your website, you need to sit down with your boss and make them. Then, define your Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) and build goals based on them.

\n

The most important thing to consider when making metrics for your website is mapping them back to business goals. A metric that doesn’t match company or department goals will be easily overridden by the next “emergency” and won’t protect you from firefighting in the future.

\n

Once you’ve set your goals and KPIs, all your tasks should explicitly support them.  Keep an updated list of all your tasks, which goals they support, and what priority level they are. The next time your boss comes to you with another fire to put out, show them your task list and what you’re currently working on, and ask them to prioritize the fire. If your goals and KPIs are clearly tied to the company/department’s goals and you explain that putting out this fire will delay your other objectives, chances are they’ll rethink the importance level of the new task. This is especially true if you’ve already had a productive discussion about the detriment to your productivity posed by firefighting.

\n

However, some level of firefighting will always be a part of every job, which is why this section is titled “Make Yourself Flame Retardant” instead of “Make Yourself Fireproof.” Be flexible to the needs of your boss, and understand that they may be coming to you due to pressure from the people above them. They might appreciate the assistance so much, they’ll let you do your job!

\n

 

\n

Get tips and best practices for your next website redesign project:

\n

\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Top-Down, Bottom-up: 2 Approaches to Better Web Governance at Your University

\n

I have heard it said that if a university was a country, it would last about a week before breaking apart in civil war. At first brush it sounded ridiculous, but now I think it actually makes a good bit of sense. Think about it – a university: Has a large population. Is highly diverse….

\n
\n

BY Dave Schneider

\n

9. Apr 2014

\n
\n
\nMore\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Say goodbye to inaccessible PDFs on your website

\n

”We can’t upload PDFs to our website because PDFs are not accessible“ and “We have to provide an accessible version of our PDFs since it is not possible to make PDFs accessible“ are both common dilemmas experienced among web teams. Perhaps these are sentences you’ve heard or even used yourself? It is a common misunderstanding…

\n
\n

BY Dave Schneider

\n

9. Apr 2014

\n
\n
\nMore\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Why Do My Documents Need To Be Accessible?

\n

Admit it: “PDFs” aren’t usually the first thing that come to mind when you think about website accessibility. They probably should be. PDFs are nearly ubiquitous as a “final” document type on the web, and hosted PDFs are often the only location certain content is made available – especially for educators, the healthcare industry, and…

\n
\n

BY Dave Schneider

\n

8. Apr 2014

\n
\n
\nMore\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689814130:\n\n\n\n\n\nA New Web Governance Roadmap\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n
\n

\nA New Web Governance Roadmap\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/27/13 4:46 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by Shane Diffily. The value of Web Governance is that it can deliver a minimum level of quality for both operations, and online experience. Get it right and you'll have happy users and happy staff. But no online management system ever emerges fully formed. Development, evolution and sometimes revolution are all features of a maturing Web Team. Having worked with dozens of organizations, I now visualize progress in Web Governance as a journey made up of three phases. Use the 'Web Governance Roadmap' described here to work out the distance you have covered on this journey - and what remains to be done.

\n
\n\n
\n

The value of good Web Governance is that it can deliver a minimum level of quality for both operations and online experience.

\n

But there's something to remember.

\n

Without a higher purpose, even the best governance system is like a Porsche stuck in neutral. A beautiful machine, but ultimately pointless.

\n

As such, we must never forget that Web Governance is not an end in itself. It is a means to an end.

\n

The real point is that it gives you the stability you need to focus on more important things - like your online goals.

\n

Web Governance is a journey

\n

No online management system ever emerges fully formed and perfect. Development, evolution and sometimes revolution are all features of a maturing Web Team.

\n

Having worked with dozens of organizations in many industries, I now visualize progress in Web Governance as a journey made up of three phases (as shown below).

\n

These phases reflect how an organization - and its incumbent web manager - advance towards operational stability.

\n


\n
\n

PHASE 1: Discover

\n

At Phase 1, an organization discovers the topic of Web Governance for the first time. The focus here is on learning what online management is all about and seeing how to use these ideas to put order on complexity.

\n

PHASE 2: Organize

\n

By this stage, the organization finally 'gets' Web Governance and is ready to commit to doing it right. The Web Manager is given the go-ahead to create a proper system of control, with the manpower, skills, tools, and other things needed to build operational stability.

\n

PHASE 3: Optimize

\n

You are now in the happy position of having a governance system that is broadly right. That is, you have the right people in the right roles with the right tools and the right budget, etc, with few distractions like role conflict or missing leadership.

\n

In addition, because there are so few distractions, you are able to spend time optimizing your already functional governance to make it even better, e.g. by scrutinizing the new Analytics of Web Governance I have written about before.

\n

PHASE 2+: Re-Organize

\n

It's worth noting that from time to time, even firms with stable governance may go through periods of turmoil that require online management to be reorganized, e.g. as the result of a merger, a major strategy change, etc.

\n
\n

A new roadmap for Web Governance

\n

Different industries progress at different rates along this journey.

\n

Even within industries, a wide range of governance maturity may be exhibited. Some are leaders and others followers.

\n
\n

Q. Who is best globally at Web Governance?

\n

A. It's very hard to say. Few organizations share insight about their online management. However, the Government Digital Services (GDS) team in the UK is doing some amazing work and frequently publishes about it.

\n
\n

Issues such as politics, culture, and leadership often influence how quickly an organization makes progress.

\n

To see where your Web Team sits on this journey, compare yourself against the Web Governance Roadmap below.

\n

Which persona best reflects your current experience?

\n

\n
\n

FREE download. Get the Web Governance Roadmap in PDF format.
Click to download the Web Governance Roadmap now (1.2MB)

\n
\n






\n
\n

FREE download. Get the Web Governance Roadmap in PDF format.
Click to download the Web Governance Roadmap now (1.2MB)

\n
\n

Where should I be?

\n

There is no hard and fast rule as to where you should be on this journey.

\n

That said, if you manage a web presence that is core to overall strategy and are in a mid-large scale organization, I recommend that you get to Stage 2 pretty soon.

\n

The demands of online are now so onerous and complex that flapping around the edges of Web Governance is no longer good enough. It's time to do it right.

\n

A Web Team that must endure ill-defined roles, out-of-date procedures and leadership neglect will eventually buckle under the strain. Executives who ignore this reality are putting their entire online investment at risk.

\n

Furthermore, not only is Web Governance important for risk avoidance, but is also emerging as a key element of competitive advantage.

\n

Just as we have seen other specialisms of online (such as usability, content, analytics, etc.) become important as differentiators - so too is Web Governance.

\n

An organization with a governance system that is fine-tuned for stability (zero online errors, zero operational issues) will be far more agile than its peers and able to react to opportunity faster. This is particularly important in sectors where other core disciplines have already been mastered.

\n

Snake oil?

\n

If you agree these are good reasons to get serious about online management, you're not alone. Lots of people are currently talking about Web Governance.

\n

As Gartner would have it, we are in a bit of a Hype Cycle at the moment.

\n

As a relatively new concept, lots of amazing benefits are being promised for Web Governance - some of which will certainly be delivered. But we must remain wary of the 'peak of inflated expectations' and keep our feet on the ground.

\n

There will be no quick fixes and no magic solutions.

\n

Online stability will only emerge as the result of a steady journey - one that builds a configuration of governance that is appropriate to the scale of your digital operations.

\n
\n

FREE download. Get the Web Governance Roadmap in PDF format.
Click to download the Web Governance Roadmap now (1.2MB)

\n
\n
\n

About Shane Diffily

\n

Shane has more than 14 years' experience in web governance, website management and operations. Until recently he worked as a Senior Analyst with a leading User Experience design firm, iQ Content. He now works as an independent consultant specializing in Web Governance, and is an official Siteimprove Partner.

\n

Read more from Shane

\n

Shane is a prolific author and thought leader. Check out some of his other articles here:

\n

\nCONFAB 2013 Minneapolis Roundup\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n6/12/13 2:33 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Last week the lovely Kelsey and Dave from our US office were lucky enough to attend the 2013 CONFAB Minneapolis conference. With so much packed into three days (and apparently some great food) they were kind enough to attend a plethora of talks, and take notes for those who were unable to attend. Below you’ll find five round-ups from some of the main Content Gurus were presented throughout the event – Enjoy!

\n

Top 10 Things I Hear About Content Over & Over Again, by Keynote Speaker, Kristina Halvorson

\n
\n
    \n
  1. We have way too much content – People have to learn to let go of their content
    2. \n
  2. We can’t keep up with all our content needs – Learning that content fuels communication
    3. \n
  3. Everyone is producing content in silos - Reorganize, talk, and identify “Think about the power of actually talking, the “Power of communications”
    4. \n
  4. No one is in charge of the content – Create consistent leadership, not controlling but empowering
    5. \n
  5. Legal won’t let us say that - Communicate with legal and other management teams to explain and understand the roadblocks
    6. \n
  6. We have 8,204 CMS’s and we want to roll them into one – Rework and rethink the content and strategy
    7. \n
  7. We want a single source, future friendly, and multichannel strategy – Start asking questions, relook at strategies, and start with small groups. “Start small”
    8. \n
  8. My company doesn’t get it / doesn’t care – “It’s your job to get people to care” Get your bosses to look at content like a business strategy not just text
    9. \n
  9. I feel like I’m in therapy – Tell me how you came to this process, grow, and change
    10. \n
  10. This time we want to do things right! – Toolbox communicates, and pushes comfort levels. There is no one size fits all for content strategy
    11. \n
\n

Content Strategy for the Customer Journey: Personalization Done Right, by Speaker Kevin Nichols

\n

"Personalized Content." "Right Content, Right User, Right Time."  "Contextual and Intelligent Content."

\n

These concepts are only fully realized through a customer journey—and the formulation of a content journey around that experience. But how do you actually structure a customer's content experience in a way that captures all necessary channels and interactions.

\n
    \n
  • What are the various touch points in a typical customer journey for web, mobile, in-store, and post purchase channels? Consider time, place, and manner
    • \n
  • What approaches are necessary for each? Smartphone, tablet, in-store, website
    • \n
  • How can you best position content across multiple channels to meet the requirements and needs of the entire customer journey? Research, get to know your target audience, and ask.
    • \n
\n

Experiencing Delightful Content, by Keynote Speaker Jared Spool

\n

Our users experience content in a very different way than we do as designers, content strategists, and developers. For them it’s all about the details of the experience. That means we need to know how to put the delight in the experience of the content.

\n

Banner / Advertising fun facts

\n
    \n
  • Average click through 0.1%
    • \n
  • Estimated ads that cant been seen by users 31%
    • \n
  • Clicks on mobiles ads accidentally 50%
    • \n
\n

Winning the Work: Making the Case for Content Strategy, by Speaker Ahava Leibtag

\n

How to win the trust (how to win the work):

\n
    \n
  1. Demystify the beast (help the client understand the client):  information > Content Format – information > Distribution Vehicles > Multi-channels
    2. \n
  2. Be honest: Know your limits / Access Organizational Maturity / Build relationships
    3. \n
  3. Ask artful questions: Tell me why… I’m wondering about… Help me understand…
    4. \n
  4. Be the guide not the map: Where are we? > Where are we going? > How do we get there? (solve for X) Map = Strategy / You = Guide
    5. \n
  5. Small Steps: Pilot project
    6. \n
  6. Manage the good idea fairy: build trust, listen, and tell me more about that brainstorm. Write it down!
    7. \n
\n

 

\n

Becoming a Content Hub: Moving From the Why to the How of Content Marketing, by Speaker Michael Brenner

\n

You’re more likely to do these things than click an online banner ad on purpose:

\n
    \n
  • Get struck by lighting
    • \n
  • Give birth to twins
    • \n
  • Survive a plane crash
    • \n
  • Win the lottery
    • \n
\n

This leaves marketers with 3 choices to get people’s attention. You have to pick one:

\n
    \n
  • Scare them
    • \n
  • Appeal to their ego
    • \n
  • Appeal to their business sense
    • \n
\n

“Content Strategy” defined:

\n
    \n
  • Who is creating the content?
    • \n
  • What content are they creating?
    • \n
  • Where does that content appear?
    • \n
  • Why are you creating that content?
    • \n
\n

The politics of content – Play the Game:

\n
    \n
  • Don’t walk into it trying to set rules for everyone to follow, because they’ll fight you on it. You have to get management on board first, and then it will trickle down.
    • \n
  • Set goals and focus on measurable results. Executives understand goals, and then you’ll have their backing.
    • \n
  • Foster Collaboration
    • \n
  • Editorial calendars help everyone be on the same page, and gain an understanding of what’s needed of them.
    • \n
  • Build Your Army, get everyone on your team, then success becomes everyone’s business
    • \n
\n

 

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

By taking a quick glance at mobile web statistics, we can see an obvious increase in mobile phone users. Every indication points to this trend only continuing to grow. According to an analysis by Morgan Stanley, it is estimated that the number of Internet users who access the Internet through mobile units will exceed the number of users who access the Internet from traditional computers in 2014. The analysis is from 2010 and whether the results will prove true in 2014 is hard to say, but larger and better screens on smart phones, more powerful processors and flat-rate data subscriptions have an influence on the process.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

On page optimization post panda: 3 tips to future-proof your website

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n7/18/12 5:24 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Google regularly updates the algorithm that calculates a page's relevance to a given search. Last year in February came the much debated panda update, which has since been updated many times, even as recently as April of this year. Having just returned from the Search Marketing Expo in London, we have lots of good ideas on how to ensure that the content on your website meets the new requirements.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web analytics: gathering qualitative and quantitative data

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/11/12 5:27 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In basic terms, most web analysis systems are based on quantitative data. This quantitative data contributes to general knowledge about the usage of a given website. Everything can then be broken down into numbers and graphs to be interpreted by the person responsible for the optimization of the website.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Want to understand accessibility? Participate!

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n7/4/12 10:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Why is it important to be able to use a webpage without using a computer mouse? How does it work when a web page text is enlarged? How does a screen reader interpret a web page? Get the answers to these questions and learn why and to whom this is important.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689817870:\n\n\n\n\n\nGet Ready for CONFAB Minneapolis 2013\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\nGet Ready for CONFAB Minneapolis 2013\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n6/3/13 2:45 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many people (ourselves included) are excitedly gearing up for the 2013 CONFAB Minneapolis Conference kicking off today. A great event that spans three days, this year’s conference is completely sold out - but it doesn’t mean those of you who don’t have tickets need to miss out.

\n
\n
\n

We’ll be in attendance both as participants and exhibitors, and over the next week we look forward to rounding up all the information we’ve learned and sharing it with you.

\n

To get people excited though we have decided to start by looking at just what exactly CONFAB is, and why it’s such a popular event.

The brainchild of the aptly named “Brain Traffic,” a Minneapolis based content strategy consultancy firm, CONFAB is the world’s leading content strategy conference. Bringing together professionals from around the world, the event is marketed towards those who realize the value of content – regardless of what industry they operate in.

The movers and shakers behind the conference label it, “one big party for content-loving folks who value smart thinking, voracious learning, and constant improvement in the workplace and beyond.” Following on from an extremely successful debut, the conference is now in its third year.

While the concept of content strategy may not be new, the CONFAB conference did revolutionize the way in which people around the world talk, write and think about content strategy. Indeed one only has to do an internet search for ‘content strategy’ to be bombarded with a wealth of information about what it is, and how to do it. Explaining the effect CONFAB has had on people, the organizers claim “Attendees posted recaps, held ‘redux’ sessions, started meet-ups, and shared success stories. There were career changes, new budgets, and increased influence in the workplace—all as a result of what they learned at Confab.”     

With more than 30 speakers crammed into three days people are sure to be spoiled for choice, but one lovely lady people won’t want to miss is Kristina Halvorson – the opening keynote speaker and the CEO and founder of Brain Traffic.

In our opinion Kristina is without a doubt one of, if not, the world’s leading authorities on content strategy. Having founded Brain Traffic in 2002 she has merely gone from strength to strength, and her influential article ‘The Discipline of Content Strategy’ was fundamental in bringing content strategy to the forefront.

\n

Apart from initiating her first conference in 2009 – the Content Strategy Consortium, she also published her book ‘Content Strategy for the Web’, which, at the time was the only book published on the topic, and is today considered the gold standard for content strategy literature.

So for all your CONFAB related news be sure to follow us on Twitter and Facebook, and stay posted for next week’s blog when we will delve into detail about some of the standout things from the conference. 

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

User Feedback - Building a closer relationship with your users

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n6/27/12 10:41 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Communicating with your users online often comes in the form of one way communication. This makes it hard for you to gain insight into what users actually think about your website. In this blog details how user feedback helps build a closer relationship with users, based on a case study of a municipal website in Denmark the Siteimprove has carried out since December 2011.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Four good ideas on how to find the right keywords

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n6/20/12 10:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Keywords are at the very heart of search engine optimization and finding the right keywords can make or break your SEO success. It is therefore very important to find the right keywords to target. It is impossible to optimize your website for all interesting keywords, so you will want to start out with the most important ones. Here, we will give you four good ideas on how to find the right keywords.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Awards

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n6/13/12 10:50 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n

It's official: we're fun.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Dive into search statistics

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n6/6/12 10:54 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Search statistics are not only essential for evaluating and maintaining the search function on your website, they are also useful for many other purposes. It is a free opportunity to learn about what your users expect from your website. Do you have the information users need? Is it well organized, and is it easy to click though to the pages that are most sought after?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

\nSay goodbye to inaccessible PDFs on your website\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

”We can’t upload PDFs to our website because PDFs are not accessible“ and “We have to provide an accessible version of our PDFs since it is not possible to make PDFs accessible“ are both common dilemmas experienced among web teams. Perhaps these are sentences you’ve heard or even used yourself?

\n
\n

It is a common misunderstanding that Portable Document Formats (PDFs) equal web inaccessibility but in fact a PDF is a document format that can be greatly accessible to many users.

\n

One question that many people ask is whether it is difficult to make accessible PDFs? The answer is no, it does not have to be. Here’s how you can easily improve the accessibility of your PDF’s.

\n

Best practice for PDF accessibility

\n

The best and easiest way to create an accessible PDF is to take some specific steps in the authoring process, rather than trying to fix accessibility in a PDF post production with a remediation tool. For instance, you can take the following steps when creating a PDF in authoring tools such as MS Word and Adobe InDesign:

\n
    \n
  • Define the language the document is published in.
    • \n
  • Provide the document with a descriptive title.
    • \n
  • Use built in features within the authoring tool to define headings, paragraph text, lists, tables, alternative text for images etc. These are commonly known as tags.
    • \n
  • Ensure that the document has a proper reading order for those who use screen readers and similar assistive technologies.
    • \n
  • Create bookmarks – this is a good way for everyone to have an index / overview.
    • \n
  • Make sure you save as / export to PDF in a way that keeps tagging in the document.
    • \n
  • Check the PDF after conversion using a tool such as Siteimprove Accessibility.
    • \n
  • Make sure the security settings of the document allows for assistive technologies to extract text.
    • \n
\n

Using remediation to help create accessible PDFs

\n

Any of the above steps can also be taken with a remediation tool should it not be possible to take them during authoring the original document, however, remediation is always more time consuming than having taken the steps originally during the authoring process. It is also important to note that if you need to make changes to the original document and create a new PDF, then you will lose steps you took with the remediation tool.

\n

So does this cover all possible PDF issues that may be present in a document? No, but it does address major PDF accessibility areas and will ensure that most users are able to access and read your PDFs. My personal mantra is “Better to be accessible to 90 % of your users than to 60 % of your users!”

\n

Learn more about web accessible PDFs

\n

Would you like to learn more about how you can create, convert and check PDFs, through the process of document authoring tools such as MS Word, Adobe InDesign? Or learn more about how to use checking and certain remediation tools?

\n

Then don’t wait, download our latest guide: How to create accessible PDFs now!

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Winter Analytics Checklist for Your Website

\n

\nPosted by\nKitty Ng\n

\n

\n11/19/13 10:28 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

As the busy holiday season starts, taking a step back to evaluate your web analytics will greatly benefit your organization’s understanding of visitors’ interests, behaviors and most importantly their intentions. However, certain industries have marketing departments buried with work during the holidays, while others focus on more strategic marketing efforts for the upcoming year. Regardless of your organization’s speed of business, it is important to review web analytics before the winter to ensure you are reaching yearly website goals. Here are some starting point tips for reevaluating your web analytics: 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Don't Get Schooled by Web Accessibility - 5 Focuses for Back to School

\n

\nPosted by\nKitty Ng\n

\n

\n8/20/13 10:36 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It’s that time of the year again: Students are lining up to buy textbooks and signing up for classes. BUT WAIT! You have a million back-to-school tasks to complete AND there is a line of students with accessibility requests at your door. Unsure of where to start? Keep calm and accessibility on! We’ll give you five critical places to focus your accessibility efforts first.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718667810:\n\n\n\n\n\nGoing for gold; developing an elite website\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nGoing for gold; developing an elite website\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n9/26/12 4:08 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Like an athlete at the Olympics, your website should be fit and free from injury. This way you can achieve the best performance and value from your website every day.

\n
\n\n
\n

In this blog post I've collected a few standout posts from the last six months to give you an overview of some of the disciplines you can "train" your website in to keep it competitive.

\n

Quality assurance & accessibility

\n

The first step in the battle for a gold medal is to make sure your website is free from injury. We haven't really blogged about the importance of keeping your website free from spelling mistakes and broken links, but this is an obvious first hurdle. If your website is free from broken links and spelling mistakes it's then easier for users to understand and use your content.

\n

Besides correcting spelling mistakes and broken links, it is important to make sure that your website is accessible to everybody (if you are going for the big win). Your website should be useable for users who are limited by a handicap or technology, but also for search engines. You can read more about these topics in the following blog posts:

\n
    \n
  • 3 ways to improve your accessibility right now
    • \n
  • Lend the Search Engines a helping hand
    • \n
\n

Goals, measurement and optimization

\n

In the same way as the professional athletes are constantly measuring their performance and studying videos of themselves to improve, it is important that you continuously measure the performance of your website. This will allow you to identify where there is room for improvement.

\n

Before you start measuring and optimizing, it is important that you set achievable goals for your website, and know what your level of ambition is. No athlete in their right mind dreams of winning an Olympic gold medal in the 100 meter sprint, if they only practice once a week. Setting realistic but ambitious goals that are in line with the available resources is a strategic exercise, which should be orchestrated by management.

\n

Putting the strategy to work by measuring and optimizing your website is what you can read about in these blog posts:

\n
    \n
  • Dive into search statistics
    • \n
  • Expand your analysis with an extra dimension
    • \n
  • On page optimization post panda: 3 tips to future-proof your website
    • \n
  • Create an annual search cycle
    • \n
\n

The posts I've included here cover just some of the things you can do to keep your website fit. You can get even more ideas from the other posts in our blog archive, but the most important thing is that you are aware that a website (like an Olympian) demands constant attention and improvement to be on top of the game.

\n

If you have any ideas on how to keep a website fit, or any requests for topics you'd like to see covered in future blog posts then please fire away in the comments.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Analytics\n

\nSearch Engine Optimization (SEO) and Mobile Websites\n

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n8/1/12 4:55 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Last week's blog post was about the need for mobile websites. And if your website isn't already mobile friendly, you're probably thinking of doing something about it. However, not all mobile websites are particularly search engine friendly, so in this blog post we will briefly present 3 options to help you make the right decisions on how to go about building your mobile website.

\n
\n\n
\n

First and foremost it's important to note that SEO for mobile websites is almost the same as for standard websites. The main difference is that local results are weighed higher on mobile searches. But even if you have complete control over the SEO of your website, you may still encounter problems depending on the mobile website model you choose.

1) The easiest solution (but not necessarily the best) is to do nothing at all. If you already have a user friendly and search engine optimized website, it's possible to leave it at that. Smartphones do a really good job of displaying standard websites, but often the user will have to use the phone's zoom function to be able to read the text and hit the right links and buttons. This method isn't the most user friendly, but your website will be visible to mobile users. Try to visit your website via a smartphone and test the navigation. If you get annoyed by the lack of speed and usability, you should strongly consider one of the other options.

2) Another option is "responsive design," which is about designing a website that provides a good user experience regardless of which device you use to access the site. That means the design is scalable so that the same page looks different depending on whether you visit the site via a smartphone, tablet, or desktop PC. On a smartphone, you would typically see one long column with the different components which on a desktop PC will typically be displayed in several columns:

\n


\n

From an SEO perspective, this is the best method to create a mobile friendly website. The main advantage of this model is that you only have one version of the website and one URL. This makes it easy to manage - there aren't two different versions of the site to be maintained and optimized - and you avoid taking a position on the SEO problems that can be a result of separate URLs. It also gives a good user experience because users always see the same site, although the elements may be arranged slightly different. On the downside, it often requires a redesign/adaptation of the design and code of the website. Both Google and Bing recommend this solution.

3) The third option is to create a separate website for the mobile market on a separate URL. This way you avoid making changes to the design of your existing website. One of the drawbacks of this model is that you get two versions of the website that have to be administered and maintained. However, there may well be good reasons for choosing this model, for example, if mobile users are using the site for significantly different purposes than desktop users. This example shows how the HSBC/Bank of America mobile website considers how their mobile users are typically interested in online banking and local content and making that content easily available (note how they also link to the desktop version at the bottom): 

\n

 

\n

There are different opinions in the SEO community as to whether a separate mobile URL poses a risk of problems such as duplicate content and link juice dilution. So if you choose this option, be cautious and follow Google's guidelines carefully.

\n

When choosing which way to go, it is important that you use your analytical data to assess your mobile users' behavior and develop a mobile strategy that takes into account what content your mobile users are looking for. As explained in last week's blog post about websites for mobile devices, this may also save you a lot of money.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

Dave Schneider

Recent Posts

Getting Started With Web Analytics

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/9/13 10:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In this post, you'll find a brief walkthrough of how to begin using the basic features of an analytics program. We will be using Siteimprove Analytics as our example, however the suggestions made should carry over to any program.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Dollars and Cents of Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n11/6/12 11:51 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

One of the biggest reasons we hear people say they don’t have a solid web governance strategy is because they lack the time and money required to implement it. What they often don’t realize is that time and money are exactly what a web governance strategy saves. In this post, we’ll be presenting a few examples from several other industries who have already spent the time and money to discover the savings offered by web governance.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Awards

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n6/13/12 10:50 AM\n

Simple, yet lethal SEO no-no's

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n2/19/13 3:07 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

“A website is like an island resort. It serves no purpose if no one can find it” Dr. Clinton Cimring, Trademarker of the acronym S.E.O

\n
\n
\n

While most of us focus a lot of our time and money on improving our SEO, it's often the basics that are our undoing. With that in mind, we've come up with a list of common elementary mistakes that people make time and time again. And remember if your SEO efforts still aren't paying off then it may be time to consider investing in an SEO tool that helps take the mystery out of it.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Ensuring the last laugh isn't at your expense

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n2/6/13 4:16 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

We all enjoy having a good laugh at spelling mistakes, but the real challenge for those responsible for websites is ensuring that the last laugh isn’t at your expense.

\n
\n
\n

Maintaining your website's credibility is not easy, especially given that for most of us checking spelling mistakes, grammatical errors, and broken links is hardly our must-have hobby for 2013, however if you wish to ensure your website's success it is essential.

\n
\nRead More\n

The Cost of Your Website's Broken Links

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/29/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

It may not seem like much on the surface, but deep down, a broken link is doing some serious damage to your website, your reputation, and your business. A single broken link can impact your search engine rankings, your site’s user experience, result in lost customers and revenue, or everyone’s favorite- all of the above.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Adding Context To Your Web Analytics With Segmentation

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n5/27/14 11:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In the first three posts of this series we reviewed how to identify your KPIs and the merits of Event and Campaign tracking to give you the full picture of how people are arriving at, and interacting with, your website. Now it’s time to dive into two key tactics for analyzing your collected data to aid you in providing meaningful recommendations on how to improve the website going forward. Those tactics are segmentation and adding context.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What We Learned At Confab Central 2014

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/22/14 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

What is Confab? It’s a 3-day conference aimed at sharing knowledge among professionals who understand the value of creating awesome content. People with backgrounds in Marketing, Design, User Experience, I.T., and Business all come together and challenge one another to think about things in new ways, approach problems with new tactics, and share their successes and #EpicFails in equal measure.

\n

We went as knowledge sponges. Here’s some of the stuff we soaked up.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How The Evolving SEO Landscape Is Impacting Your Website

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/20/14 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Search engine algorithms are getting smarter; Google in particular. Until recently, cramming your webpages with keywords and outbound links was enough to trick them into thinking that your website was relevant to the search terms. As more and more people began to “game” the system, Google got wise and decided to change the game. Get up to speed on the new rules.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Global Accessibility Awareness Day: Gain a New Perspective

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/15/14 9:09 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Close your eyes. Now try to read the rest of this paragraph. You didn’t make it very far did you? Imagine how difficult it would be to navigate a website or read a spreadsheet without the aid of assistive technology and website accessibility.

\n

Global Accessibility Awareness Day is aimed at fostering discussions within the design, development, and usability communities as they continue to build, shape, and influence new assistive technologies. The goal is to raise the profile and increase awareness around the topic of digital accessibility, which includes web, mobile, and software experiences. To help spread the word, we're offering our two-part Accessibility Certification Course to everyone for FREE!

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Are You Coding Your Website Data Tables For Accessibility?

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/13/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We can all agree that using an HTML table for page layout is wrong. For those of you who didn’t know that, thank you for sticking with me into sentence two, I promise this will all make sense if you keep reading. There are many appropriate uses for tables on websites, but the problem lies in understanding the proper way to make those tables accessible for all users. Don’t panic, tables are not to be feared or avoided! With some careful planning and a better understanding of the different table elements and attributes, you too can add usable data tables to your web pages.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Will the Net Neutrality Rulings Impact Consumers and Businesses?

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/9/14 9:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The debate over Net Neutrality has intensified once again and will likely continue to do so as Internet Service Providers like Comcast and Verizon push for a Federal Communications Commission (FCC) ruling in their favor on May 20, 2014. The outcome of this debate could have drastic impacts on the way consumers and businesses use the Internet as a communication and information sharing platform, so make sure you know what it could mean for you and your company.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Take a Load Off: Reduce Your Workload Through Website Automation

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/6/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We’ve all been there: deadlines are looming and there just aren’t enough hours in the day to meet them all. Website management teams are often too busy putting out fires and treading water to look for smarter ways to work, so we’ve taken it upon ourselves to do the research for you. Here are 4 great ways that you can save yourself time on things you already do.

\n
\nRead More\n

How to figure out which How-To’s to write

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n3/17/13 3:01 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

How-To’s are great. They provide answers to your customers’ questions, but they're also a great opportunity to get some relevant targeted content on your website and boost your SEO efforts. But how do you know which How-To’s to write?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n

Hilary Marsh

\n
\n

Recent Posts

\n
\n
\n

The Hierarchy of Content Needs: A New Model for Creating and Assessing Content

\n

\nPosted by\nHilary Marsh\n

\n

\n7/9/13 10:53 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by Hilary Marsh Psychologist Abraham Maslow developed a theory of human motivation that he called the hierarchy of needs. As explained in the Economist, “Needs in the lower categories have to be satisfied before needs in the higher ones can act as motivators. Thus a violinist who is starving cannot be motivated to play Mozart, and a shop worker without a lunch break is less productive in the afternoon than one who has had a break.”

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n

On-Demand Webinar: Introduction to Web Accessibility

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Does your website meet web accessibility standards? Do you know the steps to take to start making your website compliant today? Do you know about North America’s different web accessibility standards? If you answered NO to any of the questions above this webinar is a must.

\n

This 30 minute recorded webinar will introduce you to web accessibility, and give you action items you can take with you today to start making your website accessible.

\n

The Intro to Web Accessibility webinar will focus on:

\n
    \n
  • US and Canada Web Accessibility Standards
    • \n
  • Nuts and bolts including coding consistency and semantic structure
    • \n
  • Intro to Assistive Devices
    • \n
  • How to start creating a web accessibility strategy
    • \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

How To Quickly Clean Up Disorganized Web Content

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n7/8/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

\n
\n

If you’re feeling overwhelmed by the prospect of cleaning up your website content, the suggestion to “get an overview of your content” may sound glib and unhelpful, but it really doesn’t need to be more complicated than that.

\n
\n

There are plenty of tools available to assist you in putting together an overview, so there’s no reason to ever waste your time manually creating a website inventory.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

How to Stop Putting Out Fires and be Proactive With Your Website

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:24 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Everyone knows reactive marketing is ineffective, but far too many marketers are buried deep under a pile of emergencies to even think about strategic planning. What do you do when your boss comes to your desk every day to light your hair on fire with another emergency?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n

How to Win Friends and Influence Your Web Team

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n2/5/14 8:52 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Stop me if you’ve heard this one: You’re the website manager, and you’re held responsible for the quality of your web content - but you have content contributors from other departments over whom you hold no real power. That means you’re held accountable for the quality of their work, but have no way to make them actually do it. If they decide not to fix issues that come up, it reflects poorly on you. Fortunately, there are ways to manage this situation! Since you don’t have administrative influence over these team members, you’ll have to rely on relational influence – which is better anyway.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

6 Ways to Catch Website Issues Before They're a Problem

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/28/14 9:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Issues with your website can be absolutely devastating. Despite any of the marketing momentum or client base that you've built up, you may find your traffic ranking and following drastically tanking due to website errors. Lag, bad links, a lack of accessibility and even outdated content can quickly damage a website's SEO and lose the faith of its readership. Luckily, there are some ways you can avoid these issues before they even become a problem.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

5 Ways to Determine Your Website's ROI

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/21/14 9:14 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Measuring the ROI of a website is incredibly important. At any time, you may be called upon to prove that the company's website is worth the investment, or even to defend your budget - and that could mean defending your salary, too. The ROI of a website isn't always as simple as presenting "expenses going out" and "profit coming in." Sometimes you may find yourself explaining your website's ROI to individuals who don't even know how to use the web let alone understand its value as a marketing tool. Before you can appropriately measure a website's ROI, upper management needs to have specific marketing, administrative and client service goals for the site in mind. Once you know exactly which metrics the website is being judged on, you can begin calculating the website's return.

\n
\n
\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Maintaining Your Website Saves Time and Headache

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/16/14 9:19 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

“I don’t have time to quality assure my site. I’m already swamped with too many other things, and that’ll just have to wait until life settles down a bit.” Sound familiar? Time management is a daily struggle for most website managers, and all too often they deal with pressing deadlines by turning a blind eye to the quality of their website content. Unsurprisingly, this usually doesn't go well. Here are three good reasons why you actually need to keep your site the cleanest when you’re buried under a heavy workload:

\n
\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

Siteimprove Announces US Relocation

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/14/14 3:41 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove, the leading provider of Web Governance tools, has relocated their Minneapolis office due to rapid growth in 2013.

\n
\n
\n

On January 2, 2014, Siteimprove US moved into a new office located at 8000 Norman Center Drive, Suite 300, Minneapolis, MN 55437 as part of a major workforce expansion.

\n

Siteimprove’s Minneapolis branch grew significantly in 2013, adding more than 250 new customers and 13 employees.

\n
\nRead More\n

Santa Isn't Real: 4 Common Website Redesign Myths

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n12/12/13 9:38 AM\n

    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Website redesigns tend to be treated as a magic cure for a poor web presence by many digital marketers today. Unfortunately for them, separating fact from fiction can be a sobering wake up call. Here are the top 4 myths surrounding website redesign projects today:

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

5 Reasons You Should Care About Website Errors You're Not Responsible For

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n12/10/13 9:42 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

If an issue on your organization’s website doesn't fall under your area of responsibility, then it’s not your problem, right? Not so fast. Being part of a successful web team means ensuring the entire site is cohesive and error free. That means setting aside the mindset of “not my area, not my fault” and working with your teammates. Because guess what? A problem you pretend not to notice might just land in your lap later on. Here’s why you should care about mistakes in someone else’s jurisdiction. 

\n
\nRead More\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

The Challenge of Maintaining Consistent Website Content

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/30/14 11:13 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Updating your website with new content is essential for increasing search traffic, but it can also create content management headaches as your site grows and your content strategy evolves.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

Make Campaign Tracking Part of Your Website Measuring Process

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/22/14 12:07 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In order to fully understand the success of your digital marketing efforts you need the complete picture. In this post we will review a key component to capturing information you may be missing, how to implement that process in your organization and provide some guidance on how to add some serious value when you are armed with a more complete data set.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

A Look at Assistive Technology

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/15/14 10:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Assistive technologies are tools and methods used to make web information available to people with and without disabilities. With the leaps and bounds in technology the last few years, you may not be aware of all of the different kinds of Assistive Technology available.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nAssistive Technologies\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Top-Down, Bottom-up: 2 Approaches to Better Web Governance at Your University

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\n

\n4/10/14 1:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

I have heard it said that if a university was a country, it would last about a week before breaking apart in civil war. At first brush it sounded ridiculous, but now I think it actually makes a good bit of sense.

\n
\n

Think about it – a university:

\n
    \n
  • Has a large population.
    • \n
  • Is highly diverse.
    • \n
  • Is geographically distributed.
    • \n
  • Has lots of stakeholders and specialist interest groups.
    • \n
\n

So, short of calling out the troops, what can you do to get everyone acting in a unified way online?

\n
\nRead More\n
\n
\n
\n

Say goodbye to inaccessible PDFs on your website

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

”We can’t upload PDFs to our website because PDFs are not accessible“ and “We have to provide an accessible version of our PDFs since it is not possible to make PDFs accessible“ are both common dilemmas experienced among web teams. Perhaps these are sentences you’ve heard or even used yourself?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Stop Putting Out Fires and be Proactive With Your Website

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:24 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Everyone knows reactive marketing is ineffective, but far too many marketers are buried deep under a pile of emergencies to even think about strategic planning. What do you do when your boss comes to your desk every day to light your hair on fire with another emergency?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why Do My Documents Need To Be Accessible?

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Admit it: “PDFs” aren’t usually the first thing that come to mind when you think about website accessibility. They probably should be. PDFs are nearly ubiquitous as a “final” document type on the web, and hosted PDFs are often the only location certain content is made available – especially for educators, the healthcare industry, and government offices. When they aren’t accessible, that information simply isn’t available to users with disabilities.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Track Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions With Events

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website technology has evolved so fast that tracking meaningful interactions can be difficult: White paper downloads, form submissions, and even watching informational videos can all be seen as KPIs and/or MCs, but are often impossible to track with the “out of the box” functionality of most web analytics tools. If you want to track these critical data points, you need to customize your tracking code – a seemingly daunting task.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why Content Governance Drives Engagement

\n

\nPosted by\nAhava Leibtag\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In honor of President’s Day, my husband and I took our three children to the American Museum of History, a branch of the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C. While we were putting our coats in lockers, I saw something that surprised me:

\n
\n

Does stash seem like a word that is in line with Smithsonian brand? Stash feels a little too irreverent to be a Smithsonian word. Yet, when I saw this sign, it became clear to me:

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Identifying Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions on B2B Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:22 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

This past week I had the opportunity to talk to both the Tampa and Orlando City Groups of the Legal Marketing Association (LMA) Southeastern Chapter about getting value from their web analytics. As with any good analytics framework, there are some key things you can do to begin making meaningful changes to your websites based on data.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Tips for Preparing for a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nStar Bazella\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:16 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website redesign projects are all the rage in marketing today. According to recent studies, the vast majority of marketing departments have either just undergone a website redesign, or are just about to. However, many marketers can’t give an empirical reason for their redesign. They know their current website is “underperforming,” and that’s about it. Without clearly and empirically determining how and why your website is underperforming, a redesign is little more than a really expensive and stressful shot in the dark.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n9/3/13 2:14 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As smartphone sales continue to overtake the trusty old PC and mobile internet usage grows now is the time to get serious about your mobile platform. With these five simple steps below you’ll quickly be on your way to creating or improving your mobile user experience.

\n
\nRead More\n
