Why Content Governance Drives Engagement

\n

\nPosted by\nAhava Leibtag\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In honor of President’s Day, my husband and I took our three children to the American Museum of History, a branch of the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C. While we were putting our coats in lockers, I saw something that surprised me:

\n
\n

Does stash seem like a word that is in line with Smithsonian brand? Stash feels a little too irreverent to be a Smithsonian word. Yet, when I saw this sign, it became clear to me:

\n
\nRead More\n

Identifying Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions on B2B Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:22 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

This past week I had the opportunity to talk to both the Tampa and Orlando City Groups of the Legal Marketing Association (LMA) Southeastern Chapter about getting value from their web analytics. As with any good analytics framework, there are some key things you can do to begin making meaningful changes to your websites based on data.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Tips for Preparing for a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nStar Bazella\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:16 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website redesign projects are all the rage in marketing today. According to recent studies, the vast majority of marketing departments have either just undergone a website redesign, or are just about to. However, many marketers can’t give an empirical reason for their redesign. They know their current website is “underperforming,” and that’s about it. Without clearly and empirically determining how and why your website is underperforming, a redesign is little more than a really expensive and stressful shot in the dark.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Q&A on the Basics of Web Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n2/11/14 9:01 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

We get a lot of questions on web accessibility here at Siteimprove, and want to take this opportunity to answer as many of them as we can. This may be more of a review for you seasoned accessibility folks, but there’s a growing demand for this introductory information as more web professionals recognize the importance of accessibility. 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Win Friends and Influence Your Web Team

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n2/5/14 8:52 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Stop me if you’ve heard this one: You’re the website manager, and you’re held responsible for the quality of your web content - but you have content contributors from other departments over whom you hold no real power. That means you’re held accountable for the quality of their work, but have no way to make them actually do it. If they decide not to fix issues that come up, it reflects poorly on you. Fortunately, there are ways to manage this situation! Since you don’t have administrative influence over these team members, you’ll have to rely on relational influence – which is better anyway.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

6 Ways to Catch Website Issues Before They're a Problem

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/28/14 9:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Issues with your website can be absolutely devastating. Despite any of the marketing momentum or client base that you've built up, you may find your traffic ranking and following drastically tanking due to website errors. Lag, bad links, a lack of accessibility and even outdated content can quickly damage a website's SEO and lose the faith of its readership. Luckily, there are some ways you can avoid these issues before they even become a problem.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

5 Ways to Determine Your Website's ROI

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/21/14 9:14 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Measuring the ROI of a website is incredibly important. At any time, you may be called upon to prove that the company's website is worth the investment, or even to defend your budget - and that could mean defending your salary, too. The ROI of a website isn't always as simple as presenting "expenses going out" and "profit coming in." Sometimes you may find yourself explaining your website's ROI to individuals who don't even know how to use the web let alone understand its value as a marketing tool. Before you can appropriately measure a website's ROI, upper management needs to have specific marketing, administrative and client service goals for the site in mind. Once you know exactly which metrics the website is being judged on, you can begin calculating the website's return.

\n
\n
\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Maintaining Your Website Saves Time and Headache

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/16/14 9:19 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

“I don’t have time to quality assure my site. I’m already swamped with too many other things, and that’ll just have to wait until life settles down a bit.” Sound familiar? Time management is a daily struggle for most website managers, and all too often they deal with pressing deadlines by turning a blind eye to the quality of their website content. Unsurprisingly, this usually doesn't go well. Here are three good reasons why you actually need to keep your site the cleanest when you’re buried under a heavy workload:

\n
\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n

    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove, the leading provider of Web Governance tools, has relocated their Minneapolis office due to rapid growth in 2013.

\n
\n
\n

On January 2, 2014, Siteimprove US moved into a new office located at 8000 Norman Center Drive, Suite 300, Minneapolis, MN 55437 as part of a major workforce expansion.

\n

Siteimprove’s Minneapolis branch grew significantly in 2013, adding more than 250 new customers and 13 employees.

\n
\nRead More\n

Every web team is strapped for time, but most have no idea how much time they waste doing things manually when automated options are readily available. Here are four ways you’re wasting time maintaining your organization’s website.

\n

As smartphone sales continue to overtake the trusty old PC and mobile internet usage grows now is the time to get serious about your mobile platform. With these five simple steps below you’ll quickly be on your way to creating or improving your mobile user experience.

The Eight Deadly Web Analytic Sins

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n8/27/13 3:20 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With budgets continuing to tighten, and workloads increasing, analytics has become a must-have in every professional marketer’s toolbox. However, for many it is still difficult to distinguish between reliable data and valid data. The difference is essentially the way in which the analytics data is set up and subsequently interpreted. In the following eight points we will show how you can end up with data that looks reliable but that is unfortunately not valid by committing a few simple sins.

\n
\nRead More\n

It’s that time of the year again: Students are lining up to buy textbooks and signing up for classes. BUT WAIT! You have a million back-to-school tasks to complete AND there is a line of students with accessibility requests at your door. Unsure of where to start? Keep calm and accessibility on! We’ll give you five critical places to focus your accessibility efforts first.

Rand Fishkin of Moz addressed the argument brewing in the broader world of Search Engine Optimization strategy: Link Building vs. Content Marketing. While this discussion has flown beneath the radar for most legal marketers, it is clear which side is best for today’s corporate law firm: Content Marketing.

    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Despite the web having been around for over two decades design mistakes are still increasingly prevalent. Below we list five simple, but common, mistakes to avoid when designing a website.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n

The Hierarchy of Content Needs: A New Model for Creating and Assessing Content

\n

\nPosted by\nHilary Marsh\n

\n

\n7/9/13 10:53 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by Hilary Marsh Psychologist Abraham Maslow developed a theory of human motivation that he called the hierarchy of needs. As explained in the Economist, “Needs in the lower categories have to be satisfied before needs in the higher ones can act as motivators. Thus a violinist who is starving cannot be motivated to play Mozart, and a shop worker without a lunch break is less productive in the afternoon than one who has had a break.”

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Putting a Face on Accessibility Part II

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n7/1/13 10:21 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Professor Chris Olson has had a really busy year. Chris recently bought and moved into a house. Like many home purchases, there was a bit of remodeling that took place before the move to make the space more usable. Chris will be sharing that new home with his fiancé Cindy. Chris and Cindy were engaged on New Year’s Eve. Chris has been teaching graduate and undergraduate level computer and web programming classes for the past seven years. In March 2013, he successfully defended his doctoral dissertation, “Awareness of Accessibility in Computer-based Instructional Materials and Faculty Demographics in South Dakota Public Universities.”

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

While most of us would probably prefer to use our summer time enjoying the weather, it can be the ideal opportunity to give our websites ...

\n

\nUser Feedback - Building a closer relationship with your users\n

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n6/27/12 10:41 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Communicating with your users online often comes in the form of one way communication. This makes it hard for you to gain insight into what users actually think about your website. In this blog details how user feedback helps build a closer relationship with users, based on a case study of a municipal website in Denmark the Siteimprove has carried out since December 2011.

\n
\n\n
\n

Make your users web ambassadors and build a close relationship

\n

By creating an opportunity for user feedback on the website you have the possibility to create a closer relationship with your users and thereby minimize the risk of a bad user experience and the prospect of users swopping to other more costly channels of communication.

\n

User feedback is extremely valuable as it makes it easy for you to convert actual user experience into online improvements; here are a few examples of real user feedback:

\n

Feedback relating to web content and usability:

\n

"I'm looking for a phone number I can call for questions relating to issuing a new passport, but I can't find it on the page!"

\n

Feedback relating to self-service solutions and web forms

\n

"I'm experiencing problems downloading the forms on this site on a Mac?"

\n

Feedback relating to seasonal changes

\n

"I've spent a lot of time looking for opening hours during Easter, but couldn't find them."

\n

If your users feel you listen there's a great chance that they will change their role from simple users to web ambassadors telling others about their successful experience and maybe even give feedback on other issues on you website.

\n

Cure your blindness

\n

You can probably find your way around your website in your sleep, but this often makes you blind to navigating your website from an outside perspective. So why not ask your users if they find what they are looking for on the website? This way you get an extra set of eyes and thereby cure your blindness.

\n

User feedback - the cherry on top of your web analysis

\n

When implementing a user feedback tool on your website I would recommend you look for a tool that integrates with your web analysis service. Think of the extra dimension you could add to your web analysis data by being able to filter user ratings and comments on your most visited and/or important pages!     

\n

"We spend a lot of resources analyzing the overall visits and user behavior on our website but at the end of the day the figures do not give us a clear understanding as to whether or not the users actually find what they are looking for online. Therefore we are very happy with our new feedback module. The feedback helps us continuously improve the website, get rid of any errors and get an overview of "what works and what does not." All with the objective of making the website as user friendly as possible,"

\n

-Anja Flebbe, Web and multimedia staff, The Municipality of Horsens.

\n

Allocate resources and prepare yourself for straightforward feedback

\n

Before you open up for user feedback on your website, there are two things you may consider.

\n
    \n
  1. Allocate the necessary resources so that users find that their feedback is taken seriously.
     When opening up a new channel you must be prepared to take action and implement the constructive criticism and new ideas on your website. Depending on the size of your website, the amount of feedback may vary. During February to March 2012, the Danish Municipality of Horsens, got 700 ratings and comments on the website.
    2. \n
    \n
  1. Feedback with no filter. 
     Users tend to take their time to give feedback when they are either very happy or dissatisfied with your website. When giving feedback users are normally anonymous which means that comments are unfiltered. Therefore I would recommend identifying a group of web administrators who act as a filter and only pass on the constructive comments to the rest of the web team and editors. 
    2. \n
\n

About user feedback

\n

There are many different user feedback services. Siteimprove's new User Feedback module is an add on service to Siteimprove Analytics.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718699280:\n\n\n\n\n\nWant to understand accessibility? Participate!\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nWant to understand accessibility? Participate!\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n7/4/12 10:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Why is it important to be able to use a webpage without using a computer mouse? How does it work when a web page text is enlarged? How does a screen reader interpret a web page? Get the answers to these questions and learn why and to whom this is important.

\n
\n\n
\n

On May 9th the first Global Accessibility Awareness Day was held. I see this as a great opportunity to make an extra effort to spread the knowledge and understanding of digital accessibility. I started at home by encouraging my colleagues here at Siteimprove to take part in the event.

\n

They were all encouraged to work on the web for a half hour to an hour in one of the following ways:

\n
    \n
  • Put the computer mouse away and navigate solely by the use of the keyboard
    • \n
  • Disable style sheets in the browser and browse web pages this way
    • \n
  • Enlarge content in the browser 200 % as a minimum and even better 400 %, 600 % or 800 %
    • \n
\n

And why is this a good exercise you might ask? It is a good exercise because many who are familiar with accessibility guidelines do not have the insight of why the rules are there. Even though you might at some point have been informed about the impact it has on your work, one might quickly forget to integrate accessibility in one's working procedure. At Siteimprove, accessibility is an integrated part of every day's work but it is still a good exercise helping the attitude towards the area to have a basic understanding of WHY it is important and not just considered another set of rules one has to comply with.

\n

Many computer users cannot use a computer mouse, and have to navigate from the keyboard alone. It can be a big problem for them if some elements on a web page can only be accessed with a computer mouse. Some people use screen reader software that renders the web content to the user in one long sequence. The experience can be compared to viewing a page without design (style sheets) for a visual user. Because of this, it's important to screen reader users that content be rendered in a meaningful sequence.

Another group often experiencing accessibility issues are the visually impaired, who need to enlarge content on a web page in order to be able to read the text. It is a common problem for these users that elements or text on the webpage disappears or overlaps when the text is enlarged. Because of these different user scenarios containing accessibility issues, three of the criteria for web accessibility cover the following: All content on a web page must be accessible from the keyboard alone (criteria 2.1.1). The content of a web page must be presented in a meaningful sequence programmatically (criteria 1.3.2) and the size of text can be resized and as a minimum be enlarged 200 % (criteria 1.4.4). 

\n

Many of my colleagues were happy to take up the challenge and considered it to be a great learning experience. Most of them reported that after just 10-20 minutes they were profoundly frustrated about things like reading a web page with text enlarged: "it was simply a pain having to scroll so much just to accomplish any little thing. What a hassle!". Others were frustrated with encountering functionalities on a web page that could not be accessed with the keyboard: "I wish more web editors took on these type of challenges in order to understand how disabled people may experience the web".

\n

In general the feedback was that this type of exercise helps the understanding of the challenges that accessibility problems entail for users: "Seriously though, this is hard and my appreciation for those that are physically impaired has risen tremendously!" 

\n

So, I would like to encourage everyone who works with web to do the following: Choose one of the criteria in the web accessibility guidelines and simulate a user scenario that enables you to have a better understanding of why accessibility guidelines are important. You can start with one of the scenarios recommended by the people behind Global Accessibility Awareness Day.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why You Might Want To Rethink That Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n1/6/15 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Redesigning your website and expecting all of your problems to disappear is like buying a new house because you’re too lazy to clean the one you live in now. Oh, it'll look nice for a while, but eventually you’ll be up to your armpits in clutter again. The same goes for your website. Slapping on a fresh coat of paint might make it look shiny and sleek, but the fundamental problems will remain below the surface.

\n

Spending time, money, and energy on driving traffic to a broken website is a massive waste of resources. Users might be flooding your site, but if all they find are broken links, poor navigation, a lack of direction, and accessibility issues, the frustrating experience will turn them off for good.

\n

The good news? These are all issues that can be addressed on your existing site. So, what can you do instead?

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Step 1: Write Well. Step 2: Be Successful.

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/16/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The written word has been the cornerstone of human communication since roughly 3,000 B.C. I might be a little biased here, but even as we’ve moved from stone, to pen, to the ever-present keyboard, how you write is more important than ever. The Internet demands good writing. In the Digital Age, your audience’s first interaction with you/your company is often with the words you’ve written. Websites, blogs, social media, email; it’s all vying for the attention of an audience with debilitating A.D.D., and the organizations that prioritize the quality of their web content are the ones who will rise to the top.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Producing High-Quality Web Content: A Guided Tour

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/9/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

If you're one of those people who can just wake up in the morning, pour yourself a cup of your preferred breakfast-time libation, and start pounding away at your keyboard until something great comes out, we’re officially fighting and I’d like you to leave now.

\n

OK, good. They’re gone.

\n

For us common-folk, creating great content takes time, and it doesn’t happen in a vacuum. It requires a team-effort, as you’ll need input from subject matter experts and buy-in from your co-workers/bosses in order to turn a slab of rock into a piece of chiseled marble.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Can SEO Benefit Brick & Mortar Banks?

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/18/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Online banking is awesome. Everyone knows that. Checking balances, paying bills, transferring money, even depositing checks; online banking has made it easy for people to manage their basic finances from the comfort of their home computer or mobile device.

\n

But what about more complicated financial activities like applying for home and auto loans, planning for retirement, savings investments, or managing small business expenses? The average person will have questions. They’ll need information on how to start planning and who to trust with their money. And where does the average person begin their search for answers? That’s right, online.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Content, Your Audience, and Search Engines

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/28/14 10:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Quality over quantity, right? “But wait”, you say. “I thought that adding more content and blogs would help boost my site’s SEO rankings?” Well, yes and no. Simply cramming your website full of unfocused, aimless ramblings is actually a sure fire way to earn the ire of both your readers and that company whose name rhymes with “Moogle”. It’s Google. I’m talking about Google.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

4 Tips For A Fall Website Cleanup

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/7/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Clutter is OK on your desk. Sure, your co-workers will be silently (or not so silently) judging you as stacks of paper, coffee cups, and assorted knick-knacks pile up around your keyboard like garbage in a landfill, but it’s part of your process, right?

\n

Your website, on the other hand, is no place for clutter. Customers expect simple navigation, easy to find information, and useful content. If your website took the summer off to relax, it’s time to put it back to work.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Tips For Creating An Effective Website Content Calendar

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/30/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

With the demand for consistent, high-quality web content growing on a daily basis, creating a Content Calendar is the best way to coordinate and organize your content marketing efforts and ensure that your brand remains top of mind with your core audience.

\n

Content Calendars will vary from organization to organization, but by compiling all of your goals, assets, and ideas in a single document, you’ll be able to piece together what can turn into an otherwise unruly and chaotic puzzle.

\n

Ready? Set? Go.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n

Using Web Analytics To Improve Your Content

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/5/14 11:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

So. You’ve got a website and it’s super swanky, what with all the bright colors, pretty designs, and such. It’s also probably filled with content that you’ve spent hours creating, cultivating, and curating. But is that content any good? I mean really, how do you know? Of course YOU think it’s good, you wrote it. No offense, but you don’t matter. If your audience doesn’t think your content is relevant or helpful, then you’re just wasting words. But people don’t always say what they mean or mean what they say, so how can you truly tell if your content is resonating with your audience? Analytics.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How To Quickly Clean Up Disorganized Web Content

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n7/8/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

\n
\n

If you’re feeling overwhelmed by the prospect of cleaning up your website content, the suggestion to “get an overview of your content” may sound glib and unhelpful, but it really doesn’t need to be more complicated than that.

\n
\n

There are plenty of tools available to assist you in putting together an overview, so there’s no reason to ever waste your time manually creating a website inventory.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n

5 Reasons Why Your Website Content Isn’t Influencing Readers

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/1/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Humanizing the digital world is no simple task. Thanks to the rapid advances in technology, the expansion of social media, and the ever growing influence of the Internet, consumers are growing more and more savvy by the day. They also have more choices than ever before, which means you have more competition than ever before. So the question becomes, how to distance yourself from competitors and convince consumers that your product/service/organization is the best option for them?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8726430590:\n\n\n\n\n\nTake a Load Off: Reduce Your Workload Through Website Automation\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nTake a Load Off: Reduce Your Workload Through Website Automation\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/6/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

We’ve all been there: deadlines are looming and there just aren’t enough hours in the day to meet them all. Website management teams are often too busy putting out fires and treading water to look for smarter ways to work, so we’ve taken it upon ourselves to do the research for you. Here are 4 great ways that you can save yourself time on things you already do.

\n\n

Assistant Apps

\n

Time consuming tasks like managing new assets and doing data entry can quickly derail your workday. Luckily, there are several web and mobile based apps which allow you to automate these jobs and free you to focus on your other work. While a number of great solutions exist, we suggest trying a variety to find the best option for your business. Here are a few of our favorites that have mass appeal:

\n
    \n
  • \n

    IFTTT (If This, Then That): Is an easy to use, logic based trigger app for iPhone and Android. It allows you to create “recipes” in order to combine the functionality of your favorite apps and services. For example, IF a new photo is posted to my Instagram account “JDoe”, THEN upload that photo to my “JDoe” folder in Dropbox. Just create the recipe and IFTTT will take care of the rest.

    \n
    • \n
  • \n

    Zapier: This innovative tool allows you to leverage the benefits of multiple services and save time on data entry, inbound marketing, even social media postings. Say you’ve set up a new landing page with a form to capture data. With Zapier, you can combine your CMS (like Wordpress) with Google Docs to automatically send captured data directly to a formatted spreadsheet, saving you time and preventing carpal tunnel syndrome.

    \n
    • \n
\n

Quality Assurance & Reporting

\n

As your site grows, keeping track of every link, PDF, and piece of unique content becomes more difficult. Over time, these materials will be updated, moved, or deleted, but it can be easily overlooked without an automated tool like these:

\n
    \n
  • \n

    Xenu: This free tool may be slightly dated, but if you’re only looking to find your website’s broken links, this will do the trick. The user experience isn’t very polished or intuitive, but you get what you pay for.

    \n
    • \n
  • \n

    Siteimprove: We’ve heard great things about this tool, and apparently the employees are all amazing people. With our web governance suite, we’ll scan your site for broken links and misspellings, then provide a detailed report showing you exactly where the errors occur. It even works with PDFs.

    \n
    • \n
\n

Checking for Consistent Content

\n

Beyond the issues caused by broken links and misspellings, dated and poor quality content will also turn off potential customers. If your business has updated its branding, changed service descriptions, or needs to add legally required material to its site, you need a reliable system for ensuring that the new content is in place, but also that the old material has been completely removed. We’ve got you covered:

\n
    \n
  • \n

    Siteimprove: Our new Content Policy tool allows users to automatically identify specific words and phrases in order to ensure that your content is accurate and present on the required pages. This can help with branding consistency, content strategy, and legally required disclaimers.

    \n
    • \n
\n

SEO Analysis

\n

You’ve spent valuable time and resources on creating your site’s content, but if you’re not making it easy for people and search engines to find, it will all be for nothing. Analyzing your site’s search engine optimization (SEO) performance will help you determine if you’re reaching your audience successfully. Here are some options:

\n
    \n
  • \n

    Google Analytics: Yes, everyone knows about Google Analytics, mostly because you can get some pretty robust features for free. The downside is that you need to know a thing or ten about SEO and website analytics to use it effectively. That, and Google gets unrestricted access to all of the information it mines…hey, you agreed to the Terms of Service.

    \n
    • \n
  • \n

    Siteimprove: Our SEO tool allows you to monitor the performance of your website content with the comfort of knowing that your information will always be safe. You’ll also have access to training and support from our dedicated team should you ever have questions or need a little help.

    \n
    • \n
\n

Using the right tools for the job is how things get done right the first time. Take some pressure off of your website management team and let website automation do the dirty work.

\n

 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

\n

Why You Might Want To Rethink That Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n1/6/15 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Redesigning your website and expecting all of your problems to disappear is like buying a new house because you’re too lazy to clean the one you live in now. Oh, it'll look nice for a while, but eventually you’ll be up to your armpits in clutter again. The same goes for your website. Slapping on a fresh coat of paint might make it look shiny and sleek, but the fundamental problems will remain below the surface.

\n

Spending time, money, and energy on driving traffic to a broken website is a massive waste of resources. Users might be flooding your site, but if all they find are broken links, poor navigation, a lack of direction, and accessibility issues, the frustrating experience will turn them off for good.

\n

The good news? These are all issues that can be addressed on your existing site. So, what can you do instead?

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Redesign Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/11/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website redesign. Those two simple words are enough to make even the most seasoned of marketers break out into a cold sweat. Research, planning, meetings, debates, design, user experience, content, development, approvals, and that’s just the process for deciding whether or not you should do a redesign. The sheer amount of work needed to pull off a website redesign is often all it takes to make companies reconsider the whole idea, but it doesn’t have to be.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Tips For Creating An Effective Website Content Calendar

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/30/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

With the demand for consistent, high-quality web content growing on a daily basis, creating a Content Calendar is the best way to coordinate and organize your content marketing efforts and ensure that your brand remains top of mind with your core audience.

\n

Content Calendars will vary from organization to organization, but by compiling all of your goals, assets, and ideas in a single document, you’ll be able to piece together what can turn into an otherwise unruly and chaotic puzzle.

\n

Ready? Set? Go.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Foundations of a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nStar Bazella\n

\n

\n8/19/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Embarking on a website redesign is no small undertaking. It will require a substantial amount of strategy, organization, and company soul-searching. Not only will you need to ask difficult questions, but you’ll need to provide answers that satisfy every major stakeholder. This prospect alone is enough to deter some organizations from pressing forward, but there are steps you can take in order to not only streamline your redesign project, but ensure that everyone’s needs are met.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Tips for Preparing for a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nStar Bazella\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:16 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website redesign projects are all the rage in marketing today. According to recent studies, the vast majority of marketing departments have either just undergone a website redesign, or are just about to. However, many marketers can’t give an empirical reason for their redesign. They know their current website is “underperforming,” and that’s about it. Without clearly and empirically determining how and why your website is underperforming, a redesign is little more than a really expensive and stressful shot in the dark.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792114980:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow to be Agile in a Rigid System with Web Governance\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nHow to be Agile in a Rigid System with Web Governance\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/2/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

No organization is perfect. Big or small, B2B or B2C, every company faces challenges when it comes to managing their online presence. Resources are scarce, money is tight, and office politics might make you feel like you’re playing the Game of Thrones. You need help to address these issues and find a solution that gets results.

\n\n

I actively chose not to title this blog, “Web Governance Hacks” for two reasons. First, because I’m a snob and I hate “click bait” content. Second, and more importantly, because that’s not what web governance is. It’s not a piece of gum that you use to plug the hole in the dam. Web governance is a combination of long-term strategies and systems that allow your web team to make the most of their time and energy.

\n

There are four major commodities that typically impact how organizations maintain their website: people, time, tools, and money. Let’s dive into these areas and look at how web governance can help improve your site without feeling like you’re trying to get access to nuclear launch codes.

\n

People

\n

As our good friend Shane Diffily has already shared, people are the most important piece of any web governance system. So what can you do to make up for a lack of (wo)manpower?

\n

When you’re stretched too thin, it can feel like you’re constantly putting out fires and coming up with solutions that don’t actually solve the problem, they just slow the burn rate. A web governance strategy will help to clearly define the roles and responsibilities for your team, and help eliminate confusion or miscommunication when tackling website issues. You can put people in charge of specific tasks or sections of the website, either way they’ll be accountable for progress/success, and know exactly when to step in and address problems.

\n

Once you’ve clearly identified the “who, what, when, where, why”, your team can be more proactive, and focus on improving your website’s quality and functionality, while leaving room and establishing a plan for handling unexpected issues.

\n

Time

\n

There’s only so much in a day, and that thing you thought would only take ten minutes is now rolling into hour five and crushed any dreams you had of taking a lunch break. Organizations can hire more, spend more, and “synergize” more, but time is a finite resource, so you need to be efficient with how you use it.

\n

A web governance strategy (and tool) will enable you to prioritize errors based on urgency and the impact they have on your website. If a broken link is discovered on your website, but you don’t know how many pages it’s affecting, or how long it’s been there, you might be wasting time and energy fixing something that no one else even knows about.

\n

Web governance will help determine how these issues are prioritized, and how your team responds to them, meaning their time will be spent on projects that will have the greatest impact.

\n

Tools

\n

Carpenters need hammers, farmers need plows, and accountants need calculators. Without the proper tools, people will be less effective at their doing their jobs. The same goes for digital marketers.

\n

By itself, a web governance tool is incredibly powerful; automating the time-consuming manual tasks of checking for broken links and misspellings, catching web accessibility issues, monitoring for SEO errors, and reporting on site performance and down-time.

\n

Your web governance tool can also amplify the effectiveness of other tools, like your CMS (content management system). Your web governance tool can alert you to errors on your website, but also provide a seamless transition into your CMS, allowing you to address the error quickly and easily.

\n

While your team is hard at work creating content, improving your web design, and dissecting analytics data, a web governance tool will be meticulously scanning your website for errors that would either take too long for your team to discover, or go unnoticed entirely.

\n

Money

\n

Budgets are fickle creatures. Constantly shrinking and shifting, forcing you to find creative solutions in order to get things done. Since most executives speak the language of “results”, employing a stop-gap strategy for addressing your website issues probably won’t do you any favors when it comes to asking for a bigger allowance.

\n

So, how can you use web governance to navigate the treacherous waters of corporate budgets, roadblocks, and red tape? By speaking the same language as the people holding the checkbook.

\n

Lay out a clear plan for how your team will employ a web governance strategy (and tools) to help the organization reach its business goals. Let’s say your organization wants to increase the sales of a specific product. If you can demonstrate how your web team’s new strategy will provide the structure, stability, and focus needed to help reach that goal, you’ll be able to convince the suits to open up their piggybank and provide you with the resources needed.

\n

Web governance let's you work smarter, not harder. Get your stretegy off the ground with this on-demand webinar from Shane Diffily.

\n

\n \n \n

\n

Image courtesy of renjith krishnan at FreeDigitalPhotos.net

\n
\n

\n

\nLearning From Web Governance Anarchy In The U.K\n

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\nFind me on:\n
\nTwitter \n
\n
\n

\n

\n9/2/14 9:59 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Have you ever heard the expression "democracy is a precious ambrosia carried around in the rusty bucket of human endeavor"?

\n

Well, rarely has that bucket been more rusty than when applied to governmental web governance.

\n

Experience shows that after lots of initial enthusiasm and conspicuous spending, many official sites quickly go into decline.

\n

The problem is that creating a website is now a box-ticking exercise - characterized by poorly understood goals and inadequate support.

\n

Thankfully, that is starting to change. 

\n

\n

Tides of Change

\n

A new recognition of the need to spend wisely is creating a more mature approach to Web Governance. One of the leading proponents of this change is the UK government, which since 2010 has undertaken a huge project to centralize hundreds of state bodies and ministerial departments into a single online presence.

\n

At the beginning of this project a series of recommendations were made regarding online operations. The result was a new body with the authority to lead all online development and set the rules by which things must be done. 

\n

Back in 2009, I wrote that government would often be far better off spending its web budget “on newspaper ads, on door-to-door visits, on sky writing aeroplanes, on anything” – just not another unsupported site!

\n

Of course, I am not the only person who thought so.

\n

“It’s Groundhog Day. Hundreds of millions of dollars, large-scale IT enterprise technology, no real user testing, no real focus on users, all done behind a black box.”

\n

These are the words of Mike Bracken, describing his dismay at the problems experienced by Healthcare.gov last year.

\n

And there are some excellent reasons to listen to Mike.

\n

As Executive Director of Digital for the UK government he has led the greatest transformation yet in how state services are delivered online.

\n

Anarchy in the UK

\n

It was in response to precisely the type of issues seen on Healthcare.gov, that in 2010 the British cabinet commissioned a critique of its digital footprint.

\n

The report concluded that things were coming perilously close to the classic definition of insanity - “doing the same thing over and over again while expecting different results.“

\n

To turn things around, a revolution would be needed – and not just in the usual things like design & content, but also in leadership and authority.

\n

For example, one of the report’s key recommendations was to “appoint a new CEO for Digital with absolute authority over the user experience across all government online services and the power to direct all government online spending”.

\n

Note the use of the words “absolute authority”.

\n

Everyone knew that the scale of change required would be doomed in the absence of strong leadership.

\n

To its credit, the British cabinet responded by appointing Mike with a remit to be the “unequivocal owner of high quality user experience between people and government” and “the engine room of digital service provision”.

\n

It was at this point that official bureaucracy could start to show its positive side. For although it may take a long time to get going, when government does decide to act, it can do amazing things - simply because of its unrivalled access to power and finance.

\n

The most visible aspect of this change was the centralization of literally hundreds of state bodies and ministerial departments into a single online presence aimed at the entire population – no mean feat, considering the UK has more people than California and Texas combined.

\n

This was further reinforced by the adoption of a Digital by Default strategy, whereby all services must conform to prescribed standards for design, content, interaction & more.

\n

Already the benefits and savings have started to show:

\n
    \n
  • Gov.uk now handles 1.5 billion transactions per year.
    • \n
  • Cost per transaction is down by 10%.
    • \n
  • Annual savings in real terms are £1.4bn.
    • \n
\n

Government Digital Services Team

\n

Perhaps the most compelling aspect of the change has been the sophistication of Mike’s approach to Web Governance.

\n

I frequently point out that online failure is “designed into” a system when web ambition is not balanced by an investment in the resources needed to make it happen. The result is that teams become overloaded, quality suffers, targets are missed and things fall apart.

\n

What is revealing about the UK is just how much effort went into getting web governance right.

\n

Not only was Mike given a clear vision of everything he needed to achieve, but also a generous budget for the people, processes, tools & technology required to get there.

\n

Core to this was the creation of a Government Digital Services team (or GDS).

\n

GDS works in much the same way as the Shared Digital Units recommended by governance commentator Didier Bonnet at Cap Gemini, and also seen in organizations such as Pfizer and Starbucks.

\n

The role of such a team is to:

\n
    \n
  • Drive online strategy and development.
    • \n
  • Set and enforce standards.
    • \n
  • Be a home for core skills and manpower.
    • \n
\n

Well over 300 people now work within GDS, with many more in subsidiary units. 

\n

GDS also puts tremendous effort into sharing what it does. In fact, the professionalism of its internal communications easily matches that of the websites it creates for the public.

\n

No More Waterfall

\n

Of course, it would be naïve to think this happened easily. It didn’t.

\n

It required a cultural shift away from the waterfall-type development that led Healthcare.gov into such a mores, and towards modern Agile techniques.

\n

But it worked, and it is now clear that the US wants follow where the UK has led.

\n

For instance, only a couple of weeks ago a new Digital Services team and Digital Services Playbook was announced at the White House by Chief Technology Officer, Todd Park.

\n

The influence of the GDS model is obvious.

\n

In fact, Mike and his team welcome other governments borrowing and re-using their ideas. “My hope is that the [healthcare.gov] shockwaves … are strong enough to implement a new approach, to get political will behind having digital skills in the center.”

\n

The great advantage is that everything Gov.uk does is available online for free and can be accessed by anyone – including you. I strongly recommend that you visit their site to explore such things as:

\n
    \n
  • Service Design Manual.
    • \n
  • Web Team Job Descriptions.
    • \n
  • Agile Process overview.
    • \n
\n

I also urge you to catch-up with the back story of GDS and keep in touch with current developments by subscribing to the GDS blog. It provides unprecedented insight into the challenges, triumphs and (sometimes) failures of large scale governance change.

\n

 

\n

Finally, if you thirst for even more, join me in my webinar on September 10th when I’ll be exploring the GDS team in more detail and homing in on the best ideas to use for your own online operations.

\n

\n \n \n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9028100480:\n\n\n\n\n\nWeb Accessibility and Our Aging Population\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

On-Demand Webinar: Web Accessibility & Our Aging Population

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

We’ve mentioned in previous webinars that approximately 20% of our population is living with some form of disability—of varying severity. That statistic, it seems, may be on the rise as medical and technological advances have led to a prolonged life expectancy for a generation that actually remembers what life was like before the Internet.

With age comes the potential for impairments or disabilities that make it difficult to manage our day-to-day activities. One of those activities involves our interaction with the Internet and the devices we use to access it. In this accessibility webinar, we talk about the importance of accessible coding practices that affect our older population. Topics will include:

\n
    \n
  • Which ailments are factors to consider
    • \n
  • How technology and devices are changing
    • \n
  • The multiple uses of the Internet for tasks that may not have been available in the past
    • \n
  • The business case
    • \n
\n

 

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Government

\n

As government agencies increasingly look to reduce costs and improve efficiency by encouraging users to access government services online, the need for good web governance tools increases. Siteimprove can help!

\nRequest a Demo\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove for Government Agencies

\n

Find broken links and misspellings, ensure information’s credibility, see WCAG 2.0 and Section 508 issues and make your Government website truly web accessible, monitor response times, and help users find the information they need.

\n

 

\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n

    Check website accessibility issues WCAG 2.0

    \n

    Issues and Guidelines in Siteimprove Accessibility checks and identifies the WCAG 2.0 success criteria conformance levels A, AA and AAA for ensuring accessible web content. For instance, missing text alternatives, such as success criteria 1.1.1 Non-text Content which affects screen readers accessing images and even search engine performance. Siteimprove Accessibility also helps list and prioritize errors, flags warnings and allows you to review and ignore WGAG 2.0 issues accordingly.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Simple HTML and CSS W3C web page validation

    \n

    Siteimprove Accessibility Issues and Guidelines also checks and evaluates your website’s HTML and CSS markup in conformance with W3C standards to quickly identify those portions of your website that need your attention. Code which is marked up in line with W3C is seen as good web practice and improves website accessibility and search engine visibility.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Stress-free Language Management

    \n

    Easily see every spelling mistake on your website, and utilize the powerful dictionary editing features to eliminate false positives and proactively flag inappropriate words. Plus if you were to accidentally add a misspelled word to the dictionary it’s no problem as all changes can be reviewed and edited.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Quickly Identify Broken Links

    \n

    Siteimprove’s crawlers check every link on every single page of your site so that you don’t have to. With options to filter broken links by internal and external, you can quickly see where the problem lies. Plus run reports at any time to instantly see your progress.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Schedule and Customize Reports

    \n

    Siteimprove Quality Assurance custom reports are delivered directly to your inbox, with prioritized error lists directing your attention to where it’s needed most. Plus generate, schedule and customize unlimited report templates to suit you or your staff’s needs.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

What's included?

\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    \nEXPERT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE

    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    \nOn-going
    \nTraining

    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n

    \nServices

    \n
    • \n

    \n\n
    \n

    \nFull Upgrade
    \nProtection

    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    \nUnlimited
    \nUsers

    \n

Happy clients

\n

Here's what they have to say about us

\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    Our municipality and municipal officers have a passion for inclusive environments and removing barriers, and Siteimprove Accessibility helps us quickly determine exactly how to make that a reality. The ability to log in from any computer and for the product to connect directly to our web content management system saves us a bundle of time, and the way it breaks down web accessibility errors and notifications by priority compliance levels keeps our editors from getting overwhelmed.

    \n
    \nCoordinator of Customer Service at Town of Huntsville
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    Siteimprove gives us peace of mind managing a site with many content contributors. With so many moving parts, mistakes have a way of finding their way onto a website regardless of the safeguards in our CMS, and Siteimprove makes it easy and efficient to catch them when they happen. Siteimprove has saved countless hours and grey hairs since we began using them in 2008.

    \n
    \nTechnology / Web Coordinator at City of St. Louis Park
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    It rarely happens, but when a service does what it says and provides an immediate positive impact by both saving staff time and enhancing our reputation, I feel compelled to let people know about it. I am thoroughly impressed with Siteimprove and have recommended it very highly to others. Thank you for an excellent product and keep up the good work.

    \n
    \nCIO / Director of IT Services at Metropolitan Government of Nashville and Davidson County
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    Siteimprove Analytics is filled with useful features like single page tracking, PDF, and behavior tracking. The page inventory and individual page analytics assists with my ROT (Redundant, Outdated or Trivial) assessments. Siteimprove Analytics is an invaluable tool for ensuring we continue to provide our users with content that best meets their needs.

    \n
    \nWeb Architect at City of Huron
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n

3 Tips For Creating An Effective Website Content Calendar

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/30/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

With the demand for consistent, high-quality web content growing on a daily basis, creating a Content Calendar is the best way to coordinate and organize your content marketing efforts and ensure that your brand remains top of mind with your core audience.

\n

Content Calendars will vary from organization to organization, but by compiling all of your goals, assets, and ideas in a single document, you’ll be able to piece together what can turn into an otherwise unruly and chaotic puzzle.

\n

Ready? Set? Go.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Accessibility Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/23/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Our reliance on technology in everyday life continues to grow at an alarming rate. I’m willing to wager that the majority of you are reading this on a computer, your smartphone is within arm’s reach, there’s a tablet tucked away in your bag, and you may have even snuck in some TV time today. Some of our closest relationships are the ones we have with our screens and devices, floating in the pixelated waves of the digital sea. Despite how we may feel about being so reliant on our technology, there’s no denying the benefits offered by the latest and greatest gear, gadgets, and gizmos.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Accessible Website Multimedia

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n9/18/14 12:27 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

According to HubSpot, multimedia content is more engaging and shareable than its text-only counterparts. Making this content more accessible for your users is a simple process, so long as you take web accessibility guidelines into account while adding this kind of content to your website. With improvements in bandwidth, as well as browsers and media players, you have an opportunity to deliver an engaging, rich media experience to your visitors. Unfortunately, if you don’t prepare properly, the experience will be less accessible, and more frustrating to your visitors.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website SEO Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/9/14 10:05 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

What Google says, goes. They are the Alpha and Omega when it comes to online search, and their search algorithm is what dictates how your website’s SEO needs to be calibrated. In order to receive the maximum return on your online investment, your website’s SEO needs to cross off a number of key to-do’s before it can reap the rewards from Skynet Google.

\n

If you haven’t been keeping up with Google’s latest algorithm updates, read our blog that discussed the evolving SEO landscape. Go ahead and read it, I’ll wait.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Learning From Web Governance Anarchy In The U.K

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\n

\n9/2/14 9:59 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Have you ever heard the expression "democracy is a precious ambrosia carried around in the rusty bucket of human endeavor"?

\n

Well, rarely has that bucket been more rusty than when applied to governmental web governance.

\n

Experience shows that after lots of initial enthusiasm and conspicuous spending, many official sites quickly go into decline.

\n

The problem is that creating a website is now a box-ticking exercise - characterized by poorly understood goals and inadequate support.

\n

Thankfully, that is starting to change. 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

\nWatch Out, Australia. Here Comes Kelsey.\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKelsey Johnson\n

\n

\n10/14/14 5:30 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Well, I’m headed down under, to Oz, Aussie, or whatever you prefer to call it – Let me try that again… I’m going to Australia!

\n

Over the past year I’ve had the immense pleasure of working with the Oceania region, and it’s about time that I dropped in for a visit! I’ve been fortunate to build a great network of customers, influencers, and web experts across Australia that I cannot wait to meet with and discuss how Siteimprove can continue to support the needs of web teams around the world, and more specifically, in Australia.

\n\n

So, like many of my friends and family have been asking me, “Kelsey, what exactly are you going to be doing there?”

\n
    \n
  1. Find, meet, and attempt to befriend a kangaroo
    2. \n
  2. Meet with as many current and potential customers as possible
    3. \n
  3. Learn as MUCH AS POSSIBLE about the Australian market and its web teams’ needs
    4. \n
  4. Get out of the freezing Minnesota weather
    5. \n
  5. Last but not least, Siteimprove & Deakin University are collaborating to host an Accessibility speaking event. Details below:
    6. \n
\n

Web Accessibility Event @ Deakin University

\n

We will be covering how to address accessibility issues on your website in order to reach a AA level of compliance, and strategies to make web accessibility a part of your day-to-day work on the web.

\n

Thursday, November 13
12:30pm – 2:30pm

\n

Burwood Corporate Center
221 Burwood Highway
Building BC, Level 2
Burwood, Victoria 3125

\n

\n \n \n

\n

My Schedule

\n

I’ll be splitting my time between Sydney and Melbourne, so please let me know if you would like to schedule some time to learn more about Siteimprove or how we can help you improve the way you manage your website. 

\n

Sydney: October 27 – November 6
Melbourne: November 7 – November 18

\n

\n \n \n

\n

Overall, the 4 weeks that I’ll be in Australia are to fully immerse myself in the culture, lifestyle, demands, and needs of the market so that I can work with our product team to create a more useful tool for you!

\n

Follow Me

\n

Since I’m an avid photographer, you can also follow my journey in pictures on the Siteimprove Instagram account.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

Why Blogging Should Be Part Of Your Web Governance Strategy

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/24/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The “too long; didn’t read” version? It’s good for business. Oh, you’re still there. Well then let’s elaborate on that a little bit. When done correctly, blogging is arguably the most important, and most effective, inbound marketing tactic your organization can utilize. According to HubSpot, blogging regularly will result in more sales leads, more site visits, and more social media engagement. See? We told you it’s good for business.

\n

Now, for you detail-oriented readers, let’s take a closer look at how blogging can have a positive impact on your other marketing and web governance strategies and help you reach your online marketing goals.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Accessibility and Our Aging Population

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n6/17/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

How many of you have heard the term “Silver surfer”? A Silver surfer is an individual over the age of 50 who utilizes the Internet on a consistent basis. In this month’s post, we’re going to address the issue of website accessibility and our aging population.

\n

As mentioned in previous posts, approximately 20% of our population is living with some form of disability of varying severity, and thanks to medical and technological advances, that statistic is on the rise due to our aging population.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Content Marketing and Website Governance are, like, Totally BFFs

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/10/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

“Keep telling me what to do and what to buy”, said no consumer ever. Mass marketing tactics such as TV, print, and radio were once the staples of every marketing strategy. But, thanks to the Internet, they have seen their share of the budget eaten away by a new brand of more carefully curated strategies that are able to leverage websites, social media, and email. One such strategy is Content Marketing, which aims to attract a highly targeted audience by developing and sharing content that has been designed specifically with them in mind.   

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Roles & Responsibilities on Website Teams

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\n

\n6/3/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

People are the most important part of any system of Web Governance. Hire good people and they will generally find clever and innovative ways to get maximum bang for your buck. However, roles & responsibilities have not kept pace with changes in online activity. This has led to dangerous gaps in operations, as well as tension among staff due to competing claims over “who does what”.

\n

In this article we’ll explore some of the ways you can restore 'industrial peace' by delivering the clear job descriptions your team needs.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n

Say goodbye to inaccessible PDFs on your website

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

”We can’t upload PDFs to our website because PDFs are not accessible“ and “We have to provide an accessible version of our PDFs since it is not possible to make PDFs accessible“ are both common dilemmas experienced among web teams. Perhaps these are sentences you’ve heard or even used yourself?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Raising Digital Discrimination Awareness

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/21/13 3:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Imagine that you’re suddenly blind, maybe unable to make your body function as it did before, perhaps you can no longer read without difficulty or distinguish between colors, conceivably you may just be getting older… Now try accessing the web.

\n
\n
\n

Many people find it difficult to imagine what accessing the web may be like without the basic physical and cognitive traits we often take for granted. Aimed to get people talking, thinking and learning about the estimated 20% of the population with some kind of a disability, Global Accessibility Awareness Day has again concluded for another year - but not without some important lessons being learned the hard way.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Editors: Create Accessible Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n1/29/13 9:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As a web editor you are responsible for the content you publish on the website and it’s accessibility. Do you know how to support accessibility when you write texts and add images and links on a web page?

\n
\n
\n

This is the final blog post in a series of 3 that cover websites and accessibility with a role-based approach. This post is meant for web editors. The previous was intended for web designers and for web developers. I will give concrete tips on how to create an accessible web site.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Developers: Create an Accessible Website

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n1/2/13 2:35 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you developing your website for many types of users, or are you primarily developing for people who access websites in much the same way as you do? Do you know how dyslexic users, people who are colorblind, people with impairments and others navigate the web?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Web Designer's Guide on How to Create Accessible GUIs

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n12/12/12 2:58 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As a web designer, several accessibility criteria are especially important to help you ensure as many users as possible can use your web application.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Integrate Accessibility in Your Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n11/21/12 3:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Web accessibility isn’t something that is ensured solely through a website development project. To be successful, accessibility has to be a part of the overall web governance strategy.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

13 Tips to Improve Your Website for Mobile Users and Disabled Users at the Same Time

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n10/17/12 3:46 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Smart phone sales are exploding, and the desire to make websites accessible to all users on mobile platforms is also increasing. I’m going to give you some tips on how to create accessible web content in the best way.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

New website – Think web accessibility from day 1

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n8/29/12 4:40 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n

    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

If you are about to redesign your website, now is a good time to focus on getting a website that can be used by as many people as possible. Here are some tips on when and how to make requirements and focus on accessibility throughout the process.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Avoid These Common Accessibility Mistakes

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n8/8/12 4:47 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Find out if you use alternative texts, headings and forms correctly and if you in general help people with disabilities and dyslexia etc. on your website

\n

In this blog, we'll cover several common misunderstandings in connection with accessibility problems on websites. Find out whether your website is doing it right or wrong.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Want to understand accessibility? Participate!

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n7/4/12 10:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Why is it important to be able to use a webpage without using a computer mouse? How does it work when a web page text is enlarged? How does a screen reader interpret a web page? Get the answers to these questions and learn why and to whom this is important.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

About Siteimprove

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n

Kevin Rydberg

\n
Kevin Rydberg is Siteimprove’s Senior eAccessibility Consultant, in the US office he is responsible for guiding and supporting businesses and organizations on their journeys to create accessible websites. Kevin has spoken across the United States at multiple conferences and events, most recently at the National Council for Marketing and Public Relations National Conference.
\n
\n

Recent Posts

\n
\n
\n

Putting a Face on Accessibility Part II

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n7/1/13 10:21 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Professor Chris Olson has had a really busy year. Chris recently bought and moved into a house. Like many home purchases, there was a bit of remodeling that took place before the move to make the space more usable. Chris will be sharing that new home with his fiancé Cindy. Chris and Cindy were engaged on New Year’s Eve. Chris has been teaching graduate and undergraduate level computer and web programming classes for the past seven years. In March 2013, he successfully defended his doctoral dissertation, “Awareness of Accessibility in Computer-based Instructional Materials and Faculty Demographics in South Dakota Public Universities.”

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Kevin’s Top 10 Web Accessibility Tips

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/28/13 3:24 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Web accessibility is a complex issue, and there are many rules and guidelines that you need to be aware of as you work towards providing an accessible solution for your users. One of the most frequent questions we hear is, “where do I start?” Here are 10 items to consider when building accessible websites. Whether you are contributing content to a blog, or managing thousands of pages, these tips should put you on the right path.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Putting a Face on Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/29/13 10:25 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

All too often we forget to put a face on people with disabilities, instead we lump them into categories.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Latest news.

\n

Your one stop spot for all the latest news about what we’ve been up to, what we plan on doing, plus plenty of extra exciting announcements about everything from web governance news, customer visits, partnerships, sponsorship’s, awards and much more.

Siteimprove To Assist Minnesota Wild With Their Web Governance Goal

\n
\n

BY Callan Young

\n

20. Nov 2014

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

MINNEAPOLIS, MN – November 19, 2014: Siteimprove announced today that they have partnered with the Minnesota Wild of the National Hockey League to use Siteimprove’s web governance suite, offered via Software as a Service (SaaS).

\n

Web governance is the practice of managing the quality and consistency of your online presence through organized systems, policies, and tools. Employing a properly structured web governance framework can lead to better organization, communication, and focus as businesses strive to achieve their online goals.

\n

And that’s exactly what the Minnesota Wild have in mind. “A tool like Siteimprove will help us provide the best online fan experience possible”, said Matt Minnichsoffer, Manager, Web and Creative Services for the Minnesota Wild.

\n

The Siteimprove Web Governance Suite will also help the Wild manage their website’s accessibility. The NHL and Wild both recognize that improved accessibility will provide a better experience for all hockey fans—whether they are at the game or online.

\n

“The fans obviously come first”, said Roger Fuhrman, VP of Sales and Marketing for Siteimprove. “But from a business point of view, teams have obligations to sponsors and community partners as well. Our tool will help teams monitor their web content and ensure that their stakeholders are receiving the acknowledgement that they deserve.”

\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Releases New Trademark Monitoring Feature for Web Governance Suite

\n

Today, Siteimprove launched a new feature within their Web Governance Suite that enables users to monitor for consistent Trademark usage. This new feature allows users to ensure that names, copyrights, and trademarks are presented accurately according to organizational standards. Protecting intellectual property is essential in today’s constantly evolving digital marketplace, yet many organizations lack the…

\n
