Siteimprove Promotes From Within, Names New VP of Customer Success

\n

Software as a service (SaaS) company, Siteimprove, has named Steve Hennigs as their new Vice President of Customer Success. Hennigs has been with Siteimprove since opening their U.S. office in 2007 and previously occupied the role of Senior Product Specialist. Hennigs will be heading up the newly created Customer Success Team, which will aim to…

\n

Siteimprove Sailors Set for Success

\n

The Siteimprove Sailing Team today sets off to compete in the highly anticipated ORC International World Championship tournament, which takes place in Kiel, Germany, from August 1st until August 9th, 2014. With a strong 11-man roster, the Siteimprove Sailing Team is ready to show that web governance isn’t the only thing Siteimprove excels at. After…

\n\n\n\n\n\n 9655941980:\n\n\n\n\n\nProducing High-Quality Web Content: A Guided Tour\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n

\nProducing High-Quality Web Content: A Guided Tour\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/9/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

If you're one of those people who can just wake up in the morning, pour yourself a cup of your preferred breakfast-time libation, and start pounding away at your keyboard until something great comes out, we’re officially fighting and I’d like you to leave now.

\n

OK, good. They’re gone.

\n

For us common-folk, creating great content takes time, and it doesn’t happen in a vacuum. It requires a team-effort, as you’ll need input from subject matter experts and buy-in from your co-workers/bosses in order to turn a slab of rock into a piece of chiseled marble.

\n\n

People often ask how long it takes to produce a particular piece of content. That question makes me squirm because it can’t be answered easily. It all depends on the topic, the desired length, the goal, and the amount of research, planning, and approvals that need to be accounted for.

\n

Detailed content, like research or case studies, can easily run over 10 hours (trust me, I know), not including time for approvals and revisions. Smaller “news” articles are a little easier and could possibly be knocked out in under 2 hours if you’re already familiar with the topic.

\n

Let’s lay out the typical process for creating a piece of content and highlight what you can expect from each phase.

\n

Planning/research

\n

If you want to use the word “brainstorming” here, that’s your choice, I won’t judge you too much. I prefer to call it what it really is, the Discovery phase. This is your opportunity to identify all of the dirty details you’ll need for the project.

\n

Use this time to discover:

\n
    \n
  • The topic
    • \n
  • The goal/reason for creating it
    • \n
  • What kind of content it will be (web text, infographic, video)
    • \n
  • How you will gather your information\n
      \n
    • Interviews?
      • \n
    • External data (internal or 3rd party)?
      • \n
    • Existing content (internal or 3rd party)?
      • \n
    \n
    • \n
\n

Basically, this is your chance to ask all the dumb questions you want. And ask them you should! Don’t let things fall through the cracks simply because you assumed incorrectly or because you were too scared/lazy to ask.

\n

Write it

\n

Once you’ve finished planning and gathering intel, it’s time to put on your helmet and get things done!

\n

Turn on your out of office, activate the electric fence, or don your best disguise. Everyone has their own process, but this is your time to lay the groundwork and arrange the pieces of the puzzle.

\n

Structure and flow

\n

Once you’ve got the raw material, you’ll need to identify the “corner pieces” of the puzzle. These are the big chunks of data or information that you’ll use to guide the rest of the process and create content that flows logically and keeps readers engaged.

\n

If you’re writing a study on the growing number of marketing blogs, the “corner pieces” might be things like: global Internet usage data, the breakdown of marketing blog “specialties”, and the most sought after types of content.

\n

Title/heading

\n

The title might be the most important piece of your content. This is the first thing readers will see, and it’s probably the only thing they’ll use when deciding if it will be worth their time to read it.

\n

Titles need to be exciting and engaging, but they also need to be accurate. You can’t mislead readers with titles that aren’t related to the actual content, then it’s just lazy “click-bait”. Stop that!

\n

Quotes and captions

\n

Pick out the best quotes and data and use them when promoting your content to hook readers.

\n

Lay that text over an appropriate, eye-catching image, and you’ve got yourself a ready-made social media post or homepage image.

\n

CTA

\n

You’ve poured blood, sweat, and tears into your content. Mostly sweat. And tears. Lots of tears. Don’t let it go to waste by leaving it with a dead-end. Give the reader something else to do once they’ve finished absorbing your glorious work of art.

\n

Your CTA should provide the reader with the opportunity to find more content, or move to the next step in the conversion process. The important thing to remember with your CTA, is that it should serve the needs of the reader first, and the needs of your business second.

\n

SEO

\n

The Internet is a haystack and your content is the needle. By optimizing your content to perform in online searches, you’ll get a better return on your content creation investment.

\n

Oh, look! A helpful SEO Checklist. How did that get here? Weird.

\n

Review & Revise

\n

Proofread, proofread, proofread. Do it yourself, have your editor do it, have your co-worker do it, have your BFF do it. Heck, have your mom do it (somebody needs to say something nice about it, right?)

\n

The key to proofreading is two-fold. First, you need to get fresh eyes on what you’ve written. You know what it’s supposed to say, but that makes it easy to miss small grammatical errors and confusing sentence structure. Second, you need to get feedback from people with different points of view. This will ensure that every aspect of your content is accurate, consistent, and digestible.

\n

Subject Matter Experts

\n

Have the lead-senior-chief-product-specialist-guy (or whomever your “expert” might be) review your content for factual accuracy. They’re the ones who know what they’re talking about, so getting their sign off is crucial before publishing your content.

\n

Editor/Boss

\n

Most writers will have someone they work with/for who can review their content for consistent branding, tone of voice, and quality.

\n

Your audience

\n

Some writers may even have the good fortune of being able to release their content to a small group of users/readers who can “beta test” it. Other writers may need to rely on co-workers and friends. Try to get them to provide feedback on what they didn’t understand, questions you may have left unanswered, or content that seemed out of place.

\n

Approvals & Publishing

\n

Once you’ve made it through the revision process, it’s time to get the final approval and throw your content to the wolves publish your content.

\n

Hopefully you’re using a CMS that allows you to easily create and modify page elements, like:

\n
    \n
  • Headers
    • \n
  • Meta Description
    • \n
  • Images
    • \n
  • Links
    • \n
\n

Most CMS platforms have plug-ins that allow you to analyze the different pages elements for their SEO performance.

\n

Measure

\n

Publishing your content is only half the battle. From there, you’ll need to monitor how it’s performing. How are people finding it? Is it resonating with your target audience? Is it accomplishing the goal(s) that you identified in the Discovery phase?

\n

Your analytics data tells a story, be sure to read it.

\n

Maintenance

\n

Content should evolve over time. It should be updated with new information, and adjusted to meet the changing needs of its readers.

\n

For small changes, it’s fine to simply update the original content.

\n

For bigger changes, like new study data for example, it’s best to release an updated version of the content which highlights the new data.

\n

For those playing the home game, this blog took a grand total of 3-ish hours to plan, write, optimize, revise, and publish.

\n

\n \n \n

\n

 

\n

Image courtesy of hywards at FreeDigitalPhotos.net

\n

 

\n
\n

Web Governance Ask Us Anything Preview #2

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/29/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

As our panel of experts are busy answering the brain-busting questions submitted for our Ask Us Anything, we thought we'd share a sneak peek at the wisdom of our friend and Web Governance expert, Shane Diffily.

\n

You can download the full Ask Us Anything recording here.

\n

OK, I know. "Stop talking and give us the goods." 

\n

 

\n

 

\n

 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Web Governance Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/22/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Every organization has different goals for their online presence, a unique team managing that presence, and a distinct process for achieving their goals. What I’m trying to say, is that there’s no golden ticket, silver bullet, or metaphor in the world that will solve every organization’s web governance needs. However, there are plenty of ways to get your web governance endeavors started off on the right (or left) foot.

\n

Whether you’re just getting your organization’s web governance strategy in place, or need to get yours back to basics, here are a few areas to focus on.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Semantic Markup and Web Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n7/17/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Web Content Accessibility Guideline 1.3, “Adaptable” is defined as: Creating content that can be presented in different ways (for example simpler layout) without losing information or structure. 

\n

HTML was originally designed to deliver documents with a structure that represented the importance and order of information. The creators of HTML were actually scientists who wanted a way to share technical documents. They didn’t really care about the visual look of the document as viewed on a screen—it just needed to correctly convey the information.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Ask Us Anything Preview

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/15/14 12:48 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We're in a giving mood today, so we thought we'd share a quick preview of what you can expect to learn from our upcoming Ask Us Anything session.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n

How To Quickly Clean Up Disorganized Web Content

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n7/8/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

\n
\n

If you’re feeling overwhelmed by the prospect of cleaning up your website content, the suggestion to “get an overview of your content” may sound glib and unhelpful, but it really doesn’t need to be more complicated than that.

\n
\n

There are plenty of tools available to assist you in putting together an overview, so there’s no reason to ever waste your time manually creating a website inventory.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

5 Reasons Why Your Website Content Isn’t Influencing Readers

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/1/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Humanizing the digital world is no simple task. Thanks to the rapid advances in technology, the expansion of social media, and the ever growing influence of the Internet, consumers are growing more and more savvy by the day. They also have more choices than ever before, which means you have more competition than ever before. So the question becomes, how to distance yourself from competitors and convince consumers that your product/service/organization is the best option for them?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

Are you ready to manage smart-phone access on your website?

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/25/12 5:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

By taking a quick glance at mobile web statistics, we can see an obvious increase in mobile phone users. Every indication points to this trend only continuing to grow. According to an analysis by Morgan Stanley, it is estimated that the number of Internet users who access the Internet through mobile units will exceed the number of users who access the Internet from traditional computers in 2014. The analysis is from 2010 and whether the results will prove true in 2014 is hard to say, but larger and better screens on smart phones, more powerful processors and flat-rate data subscriptions have an influence on the process.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

On page optimization post panda: 3 tips to future-proof your website

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n7/18/12 5:24 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Google regularly updates the algorithm that calculates a page's relevance to a given search. Last year in February came the much debated panda update, which has since been updated many times, even as recently as April of this year. Having just returned from the Search Marketing Expo in London, we have lots of good ideas on how to ensure that the content on your website meets the new requirements.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web analytics: gathering qualitative and quantitative data

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/11/12 5:27 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In basic terms, most web analysis systems are based on quantitative data. This quantitative data contributes to general knowledge about the usage of a given website. Everything can then be broken down into numbers and graphs to be interpreted by the person responsible for the optimization of the website.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Want to understand accessibility? Participate!

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n7/4/12 10:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Why is it important to be able to use a webpage without using a computer mouse? How does it work when a web page text is enlarged? How does a screen reader interpret a web page? Get the answers to these questions and learn why and to whom this is important.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792109060:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow Can SEO Benefit Brick & Mortar Banks?\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nHow Can SEO Benefit Brick & Mortar Banks?\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/18/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Online banking is awesome. Everyone knows that. Checking balances, paying bills, transferring money, even depositing checks; online banking has made it easy for people to manage their basic finances from the comfort of their home computer or mobile device.

\n

But what about more complicated financial activities like applying for home and auto loans, planning for retirement, savings investments, or managing small business expenses? The average person will have questions. They’ll need information on how to start planning and who to trust with their money. And where does the average person begin their search for answers? That’s right, online.

\n\n

Here’s some stats. People love stats.

\n
    \n
  • 92% of adults rely on the Internet when beginning their search for information, products, and services.
    • \n
  • The average cost of an online bank transaction is $0.10, compared to a $0.94 cost of phone transactions and $1.00 cost of branch transactions.
    • \n
\n

SEO is tricky, and it’s constantly evolving, but there are a few tried and true methods for increasing your online search performance.

\n

Keyword strategy

\n

Don’t try to be everything to everyone. Identify what your bank does best and know what questions customers in your area have, then use that information to focus your SEO efforts on a small number of specific keywords.

\n

Use short tail and long tail keywords to expand your reach. To put it simply, short tail keywords are broad terms like “Banking” or “Auto loans”. These will help you reach a broad audience, but may not always reach the right audience. Long tail keywords are more specific terms that help narrow the search, like “Banking services in Chicago” or “Auto loan refinancing”. These types of keywords will help you hone in on a specific segment of your potential audience.

\n

Short tail keywords will maximize your exposure, while long tail keywords will help you reach the right audience and keep your costs down as the competition (and cost) for more specific keywords is far lower.

\n

Provide high-quality content

\n

Yes, ranking well for targeted keywords like “mortgage rates” or “retirement planning” is great for exposure, but you need to back up that ranking with quality content that provides usable information.

\n

You need to understand what questions your audience has, and provide them with answers that are both easy to find and easy to understand. Leave out the sales pitches and industry jargon. Most people won’t know what you’re talking about, and they need to feel comfortable if they’re going to trust you with their money.

\n

Include outbound links

\n

Search engines will view your site as a more reliable source of information and reward you with a better SEO ranking if you support your site’s content by linking to other reputable sources (outbound links), like the FDIC, Wall Street Journal, or Forbes.

\n

You can also double-dip by getting others to provide links (inbound links) to your site or blog, just be wary of link-building schemes, as these can damage your SEO rankings and reputation with customers.

\n

Leverage social media & blogging

\n

Blogs add additional pages to your website that boost your SEO performance for given keywords. You can use your blog to go beyond the information provided on your website and provide more detailed information about specific topics, address concerns and misconceptions, or provide tips and tricks for first time investors or new home owners.

\n

Social media provides an SEO boost as well, especially Google+. Yes, believe it or not, Google’s search algorithm significantly rewards those who actively post content to their social network, but they also scan Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn.

\n

Use your social networks to provide users with bite-size pieces of information that drive them to your website for the main course.

\n

Yes, the conversation will begin online, but the ultimate goal is to drive customers to your bank in order to complete the transaction.

\n

Part of the reason people love online banking is that it makes them feel comfortable by allowing them to be in control. By using your online presence to connect with them in a personal, approachable way, you’ll bridge the gap that exists between the comfort of online banking and the uncertainty they may feel over making a larger financial decision.

\n

\n \n \n

\n

Image courtesy of twobee at FreeDigitalPhotos.net

\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

Why Blogging Should Be Part Of Your Web Governance Strategy

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/24/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The “too long; didn’t read” version? It’s good for business. Oh, you’re still there. Well then let’s elaborate on that a little bit. When done correctly, blogging is arguably the most important, and most effective, inbound marketing tactic your organization can utilize. According to HubSpot, blogging regularly will result in more sales leads, more site visits, and more social media engagement. See? We told you it’s good for business.

\n

Now, for you detail-oriented readers, let’s take a closer look at how blogging can have a positive impact on your other marketing and web governance strategies and help you reach your online marketing goals.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Accessibility and Our Aging Population

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n6/17/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

How many of you have heard the term “Silver surfer”? A Silver surfer is an individual over the age of 50 who utilizes the Internet on a consistent basis. In this month’s post, we’re going to address the issue of website accessibility and our aging population.

\n

As mentioned in previous posts, approximately 20% of our population is living with some form of disability of varying severity, and thanks to medical and technological advances, that statistic is on the rise due to our aging population.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Content Marketing and Website Governance are, like, Totally BFFs

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/10/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

“Keep telling me what to do and what to buy”, said no consumer ever. Mass marketing tactics such as TV, print, and radio were once the staples of every marketing strategy. But, thanks to the Internet, they have seen their share of the budget eaten away by a new brand of more carefully curated strategies that are able to leverage websites, social media, and email. One such strategy is Content Marketing, which aims to attract a highly targeted audience by developing and sharing content that has been designed specifically with them in mind.   

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Roles & Responsibilities on Website Teams

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\n

\n6/3/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

People are the most important part of any system of Web Governance. Hire good people and they will generally find clever and innovative ways to get maximum bang for your buck. However, roles & responsibilities have not kept pace with changes in online activity. This has led to dangerous gaps in operations, as well as tension among staff due to competing claims over “who does what”.

\n

In this article we’ll explore some of the ways you can restore 'industrial peace' by delivering the clear job descriptions your team needs.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

4 Website Tasks You Should Outsource to Robots

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n12/23/13 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Every web team is strapped for time, but most have no idea how much time they waste doing things manually when automated options are readily available. Here are four ways you’re wasting time maintaining your organization’s website.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

Santa Isn't Real: 4 Common Website Redesign Myths

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n12/12/13 9:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Website redesigns tend to be treated as a magic cure for a poor web presence by many digital marketers today. Unfortunately for them, separating fact from fiction can be a sobering wake up call. Here are the top 4 myths surrounding website redesign projects today:

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n

5 Reasons You Should Care About Website Errors You're Not Responsible For

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n12/10/13 9:42 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

If an issue on your organization’s website doesn't fall under your area of responsibility, then it’s not your problem, right? Not so fast. Being part of a successful web team means ensuring the entire site is cohesive and error free. That means setting aside the mindset of “not my area, not my fault” and working with your teammates. Because guess what? A problem you pretend not to notice might just land in your lap later on. Here’s why you should care about mistakes in someone else’s jurisdiction. 

\n
\nRead More\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792118460:\n\n\n\n\n\nInvolving People With Disabilities In Your Web Project\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nInvolving People With Disabilities In Your Web Project\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n11/4/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Involving people with disabilities on your web projects may seem like an overwhelming task, but if you do, it will be well worth your effort. The benefits will far outweigh the extra work, as you'll be gaining a much deeper understanding of how users with disabilities are motivated, how efficient your site may be, and how effectively all of your users can be while using your site.

\n\n

I'll be hosting a webinar to discuss how you can benefit from involving people with disabilities in your web projects on Wednesday, November 12.

\n

For now, let's take a quick look at some of the topics that I'll be covering.

\n

Accessibility or Usability

\n

First, let's cover the common question of whether an issue is about accessibility or usability. In most cases we can say that it's both. So much of what you do to improve usability has a positive effect on accessibility. For example, a clean, well-designed navigation system makes it easier for all of your users to find the information they are looking for. Usability is concerned with effectiveness, efficiency, and satisfaction—and accessibility is considered a subset of usability—so a website can’t be considered usable unless it’s accessible.

\n

Accessibility covers a range of issues

\n

Many people still see accessibility issues as affecting only a small group of people. In fact, accessibility covers a very broad range of disabilities. On one end of the spectrum, there are those with serious mental or physical disabilities—usually pretty easy to define.

\n

What about the other end? What about people who wear glasses? People who are color-blind? Those who have dyslexia? What about those people who prefer using a keyboard instead of a mouse? Do they fall within the range of disabilities (yes!) and how do you address the issues they may have?

\n

Finding People with Disabilities (PwD)

\n

You’ve made the wise decision to include people with disabilities in your project. What next? “Where can I find a person with a disability?” you may be asking yourself. There are numerous ways to engage people with disabilities, and the ease of finding a willing collaborator may vary according to your industry and type of organization. Don’t fear; there are many great resources available.

\n

For example, if you are working in a higher education environment, check with your campus disability services office. There are students and even faculty or staff members who are willing to participate and can give you excellent feedback.

\n

When do I involve PwD?

\n

Another question that comes up as you engage with your new consultants is when to actually get them involved? From a planning point, be sure to get them involved as quickly as possible. They may not actually sit down and test your site until later in the process, but if you are not planning for their involvement from the beginning of the project, you will run into barriers that you should have already addressed.

\n

During the webinar, we will give you a roadmap to help plan out how and when to involve PwD.

\n

Range of disabilities and the needs of your tester

\n

Be sure you understand the range of disabilities you will be planning and testing for. You may need to address different kinds of disabilities in your user testing, so a variety of software and hardware may need to be assembled before you get started. Your testers can give you specific recommendations based on their experience. You may need to gather hardware or software for:

\n
    \n
  • Keyboard accessibility
    • \n
  • Screenreader accessibility
    • \n
  • Cognitive accessibility
    • \n
\n

Working with People with Disabilities

\n

A little planning and knowledge of working with people with disabilities will make your web project flow quite smoothly. Considerations may include how you plan your testing location, what conclusions you hope to gain, and a few matters of etiquette.

\n

It’s possible that you already have a suitable test environment already set up. Just be sure your accommodations for people with disabilities are really no different than you normally plan: a comfortable environment, which allows your tester to concentrate on the tasks you give them. That said, never make assumptions, speak normally, and always be aware of personal space. Given the proper setting, you will be amazed at the conclusions your testers provide.

\n

Be sure to carefully consider all feedback and avoid assuming that feedback from one person with a disability applies to all people with disabilities. A person with a disability does not necessarily know how other people with the same disability interact with the web, nor know enough about other disabilities to provide valid guidance on other accessibility issues.

\n

In this month’s web accessibility webinar, we’re going to build on these ideas of including people with disabilities in your web project. We will cover the topic in more detail and help you figure out some ways to gain even more important insights. 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792122430:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow to figure out which How-To’s to write\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nHow to figure out which How-To’s to write\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n3/17/13 3:01 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

How-To’s are great. They provide answers to your customers’ questions, but they're also a great opportunity to get some relevant targeted content on your website and boost your SEO efforts. But how do you know which How-To’s to write?

\n
\n
\n

The question is the answer

\n

Ok, that might sound stupid, but the trick to good How-To’s is ensuring that they answer actual questions from customers. One way to find some of these questions is to look at the questions users enter in the search engines to find your website. If a visitor asks a question in a search engine and ends up on a page of your website that doesn't answer that question directly, you have a chance to improve the user experience. If one person asked that question, chances are others will too. If you've written a solid answer, they could end up on your website. Who knows, they might even stick around and find some of your other content and services relevant - and before you know it they could be a new customer.

\n

Sieving data

\n

With hundreds or thousands of search terms used to enter your website, finding questions to answer may seem like finding a needle in a haystack. Filtering the search terms is your best friend here. In the screenshot below I’ve used a filter that only shows website visits where the user entered a search term with the word ‘how’ in it.


\n

The result is a very useful list of questions. Now you can find the questions you think are most relevant for your website and which include keywords you want to optimize your website for. Then it is up to you to write some quality answers as blog posts, FAQs, or whichever format best suits your website.

\n

Tracking performance

\n

The cool thing about a filter like this is that you can use the exact same filter to track the performance of your efforts.

\n

So when you’ve written a couple of How-To’s, you just have to look at your filtered analytics data, and then you’ll be able to see if traffic from the relevant search terms increase. Using the filter you’ll also be able to dive into behavior tracking, and see whether or not visitors stay on your website, and do what you want them to.

The possibilities with filters are endless. If you have any filter setups you want to share, or questions about filters, please fire away in the comments.

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n

\n\n
\n

\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9768493270:\n\n\n\n\n\nWhy You Might Want To Rethink That Website Redesign\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n
\n
\n

\nWhy You Might Want To Rethink That Website Redesign\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n1/6/15 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Redesigning your website and expecting all of your problems to disappear is like buying a new house because you’re too lazy to clean the one you live in now. Oh, it'll look nice for a while, but eventually you’ll be up to your armpits in clutter again. The same goes for your website. Slapping on a fresh coat of paint might make it look shiny and sleek, but the fundamental problems will remain below the surface.

\n

Spending time, money, and energy on driving traffic to a broken website is a massive waste of resources. Users might be flooding your site, but if all they find are broken links, poor navigation, a lack of direction, and accessibility issues, the frustrating experience will turn them off for good.

\n

The good news? These are all issues that can be addressed on your existing site. So, what can you do instead?

\n

\n

1. Determine the goal of your website.

\n

For what purpose does it exist? From there, you can make decisions that will improve your site’s user experience and help you achieve your online goals. Let’s say your goal is to increase online conversions (sales, admission form submissions, new loan requests, etc). Your site should be structured in a way that allows customers to find information and complete the actions you want them to take in the least amount of steps possible.

\n

By tailoring your site navigation and creating content that will benefit your users, you’ll begin to see progress towards reaching your goals.

\n

Disclaimer: Always remember that you are not your customer. The things that you think are important may be drastically different from what your customers think is important.

\n

Which leads us to…

\n

2. Dig into your analytics

\n

If you don’t have analytics code installed on your site, do so as soon as you can. Your analytics will tell you what your users are doing once they get to your site, what content is most important to them, how they’re getting to your site, and when/where they leave it.

\n

By understanding what your customers want, where they’re going on your site, and how they’re consuming content, you’ll be able to tailor your site accordingly.

\n

Update navigation

\n

Place the most popular/high traffic content/pages within your site’s main navigation. Don’t make your visitors traverse the maze in order to get the cheese.

\n

Monitor and modify content

\n

Some content will be a home-run right out of the gate. It resonates with readers, leads to conversion, and helps you accomplish your goals.

\n

Other content needs some TLC in order to get there. Just because a particular page or article stumbles out of the gates, doesn’t mean it can’t be whipped into shape. Try revising or re-writing it in order to increase its effectiveness.

\n

Structure the user flow

\n

Give your visitors something else to do. Once they’ve read an article or filled out a form, what should they do next? Make it easy for them to move through the conversion process.

\n

3. Make it accessible

\n

Web Accessibility is something that should come standard on every website. 1 in 5 online users is living with some form of physical or cognitive disability. Don’t alienate 20% of your audience.

\n

Not only is web accessibility easier to implement than you think, but it can also improve your SEO performance.

\n

Web accessibility is also becoming a legal requirement around the world. The Canadian and Australian governments have imposed Online Accessibility laws, and a number of US businesses have ended up on the wrong side of embarrassing lawsuits.

\n

This isn’t a scare tactic, as most organizations simply don’t know how difficult it can be to navigate the web for disabled users. However, when these users are prevented from accessing critical online tools, they’re forced to take drastic action.

\n

All of that being said, you may still require a website redesign if the systems and framework that support your site are outdated or no longer capable of handling the needs of your business. If that’s the case, be sure to check out our other website redesign resources.

\n

\n \n \n

\n

Under Construction image courtesy of Paul at FreeDigitalPhotos.net

\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign,\nWeb Design\n

Producing High-Quality Web Content: A Guided Tour

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/9/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

If you're one of those people who can just wake up in the morning, pour yourself a cup of your preferred breakfast-time libation, and start pounding away at your keyboard until something great comes out, we’re officially fighting and I’d like you to leave now.

\n

OK, good. They’re gone.

\n

For us common-folk, creating great content takes time, and it doesn’t happen in a vacuum. It requires a team-effort, as you’ll need input from subject matter experts and buy-in from your co-workers/bosses in order to turn a slab of rock into a piece of chiseled marble.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Content, Your Audience, and Search Engines

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/28/14 10:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Quality over quantity, right? “But wait”, you say. “I thought that adding more content and blogs would help boost my site’s SEO rankings?” Well, yes and no. Simply cramming your website full of unfocused, aimless ramblings is actually a sure fire way to earn the ire of both your readers and that company whose name rhymes with “Moogle”. It’s Google. I’m talking about Google.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

4 Tips For A Fall Website Cleanup

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/7/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Clutter is OK on your desk. Sure, your co-workers will be silently (or not so silently) judging you as stacks of paper, coffee cups, and assorted knick-knacks pile up around your keyboard like garbage in a landfill, but it’s part of your process, right?

\n

Your website, on the other hand, is no place for clutter. Customers expect simple navigation, easy to find information, and useful content. If your website took the summer off to relax, it’s time to put it back to work.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Tips For Creating An Effective Website Content Calendar

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/30/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

With the demand for consistent, high-quality web content growing on a daily basis, creating a Content Calendar is the best way to coordinate and organize your content marketing efforts and ensure that your brand remains top of mind with your core audience.

\n

Content Calendars will vary from organization to organization, but by compiling all of your goals, assets, and ideas in a single document, you’ll be able to piece together what can turn into an otherwise unruly and chaotic puzzle.

\n

Ready? Set? Go.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n

Website SEO Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/9/14 10:05 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

What Google says, goes. They are the Alpha and Omega when it comes to online search, and their search algorithm is what dictates how your website’s SEO needs to be calibrated. In order to receive the maximum return on your online investment, your website’s SEO needs to cross off a number of key to-do’s before it can reap the rewards from Skynet Google.

\n

If you haven’t been keeping up with Google’s latest algorithm updates, read our blog that discussed the evolving SEO landscape. Go ahead and read it, I’ll wait.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Foundations of a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nStar Bazella\n

\n

\n8/19/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Embarking on a website redesign is no small undertaking. It will require a substantial amount of strategy, organization, and company soul-searching. Not only will you need to ask difficult questions, but you’ll need to provide answers that satisfy every major stakeholder. This prospect alone is enough to deter some organizations from pressing forward, but there are steps you can take in order to not only streamline your redesign project, but ensure that everyone’s needs are met.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How To Quickly Clean Up Disorganized Web Content

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n7/8/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

\n
\n

If you’re feeling overwhelmed by the prospect of cleaning up your website content, the suggestion to “get an overview of your content” may sound glib and unhelpful, but it really doesn’t need to be more complicated than that.

\n
\n

There are plenty of tools available to assist you in putting together an overview, so there’s no reason to ever waste your time manually creating a website inventory.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

5 Reasons Why Your Website Content Isn’t Influencing Readers

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/1/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Humanizing the digital world is no simple task. Thanks to the rapid advances in technology, the expansion of social media, and the ever growing influence of the Internet, consumers are growing more and more savvy by the day. They also have more choices than ever before, which means you have more competition than ever before. So the question becomes, how to distance yourself from competitors and convince consumers that your product/service/organization is the best option for them?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why Blogging Should Be Part Of Your Web Governance Strategy

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/24/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The “too long; didn’t read” version? It’s good for business. Oh, you’re still there. Well then let’s elaborate on that a little bit. When done correctly, blogging is arguably the most important, and most effective, inbound marketing tactic your organization can utilize. According to HubSpot, blogging regularly will result in more sales leads, more site visits, and more social media engagement. See? We told you it’s good for business.

\n

Now, for you detail-oriented readers, let’s take a closer look at how blogging can have a positive impact on your other marketing and web governance strategies and help you reach your online marketing goals.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Content Marketing and Website Governance are, like, Totally BFFs

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/10/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

“Keep telling me what to do and what to buy”, said no consumer ever. Mass marketing tactics such as TV, print, and radio were once the staples of every marketing strategy. But, thanks to the Internet, they have seen their share of the budget eaten away by a new brand of more carefully curated strategies that are able to leverage websites, social media, and email. One such strategy is Content Marketing, which aims to attract a highly targeted audience by developing and sharing content that has been designed specifically with them in mind.   

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

Recent Posts

\n
\n

Why You Might Want To Rethink That Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n1/6/15 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Redesigning your website and expecting all of your problems to disappear is like buying a new house because you’re too lazy to clean the one you live in now. Oh, it'll look nice for a while, but eventually you’ll be up to your armpits in clutter again. The same goes for your website. Slapping on a fresh coat of paint might make it look shiny and sleek, but the fundamental problems will remain below the surface.

\n

Spending time, money, and energy on driving traffic to a broken website is a massive waste of resources. Users might be flooding your site, but if all they find are broken links, poor navigation, a lack of direction, and accessibility issues, the frustrating experience will turn them off for good.

\n

The good news? These are all issues that can be addressed on your existing site. So, what can you do instead?

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Step 1: Write Well. Step 2: Be Successful.

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/16/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The written word has been the cornerstone of human communication since roughly 3,000 B.C. I might be a little biased here, but even as we’ve moved from stone, to pen, to the ever-present keyboard, how you write is more important than ever. The Internet demands good writing. In the Digital Age, your audience’s first interaction with you/your company is often with the words you’ve written. Websites, blogs, social media, email; it’s all vying for the attention of an audience with debilitating A.D.D., and the organizations that prioritize the quality of their web content are the ones who will rise to the top.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Producing High-Quality Web Content: A Guided Tour

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/9/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

If you're one of those people who can just wake up in the morning, pour yourself a cup of your preferred breakfast-time libation, and start pounding away at your keyboard until something great comes out, we’re officially fighting and I’d like you to leave now.

\n

OK, good. They’re gone.

\n

For us common-folk, creating great content takes time, and it doesn’t happen in a vacuum. It requires a team-effort, as you’ll need input from subject matter experts and buy-in from your co-workers/bosses in order to turn a slab of rock into a piece of chiseled marble.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to be Agile in a Rigid System with Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/2/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

No organization is perfect. Big or small, B2B or B2C, every company faces challenges when it comes to managing their online presence. Resources are scarce, money is tight, and office politics might make you feel like you’re playing the Game of Thrones. You need help to address these issues and find a solution that gets results.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Increase Conversions with Proper Web Design

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/25/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Conversions are measurable actions that users complete on your website, things like: completed purchases, form submissions, button clicks, video views, document downloads, or specific page views. Every website exists (hopefully) with a specific goal or purpose, and while the types of conversions may vary between different organizations, they all share the same desire to provide their audience with a solution to their needs.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Can SEO Benefit Brick & Mortar Banks?

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/18/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Online banking is awesome. Everyone knows that. Checking balances, paying bills, transferring money, even depositing checks; online banking has made it easy for people to manage their basic finances from the comfort of their home computer or mobile device.

\n

But what about more complicated financial activities like applying for home and auto loans, planning for retirement, savings investments, or managing small business expenses? The average person will have questions. They’ll need information on how to start planning and who to trust with their money. And where does the average person begin their search for answers? That’s right, online.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Redesign Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/11/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website redesign. Those two simple words are enough to make even the most seasoned of marketers break out into a cold sweat. Research, planning, meetings, debates, design, user experience, content, development, approvals, and that’s just the process for deciding whether or not you should do a redesign. The sheer amount of work needed to pull off a website redesign is often all it takes to make companies reconsider the whole idea, but it doesn’t have to be.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Content, Your Audience, and Search Engines

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/28/14 10:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Quality over quantity, right? “But wait”, you say. “I thought that adding more content and blogs would help boost my site’s SEO rankings?” Well, yes and no. Simply cramming your website full of unfocused, aimless ramblings is actually a sure fire way to earn the ire of both your readers and that company whose name rhymes with “Moogle”. It’s Google. I’m talking about Google.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

4 Tips For A Fall Website Cleanup

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/7/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Clutter is OK on your desk. Sure, your co-workers will be silently (or not so silently) judging you as stacks of paper, coffee cups, and assorted knick-knacks pile up around your keyboard like garbage in a landfill, but it’s part of your process, right?

\n

Your website, on the other hand, is no place for clutter. Customers expect simple navigation, easy to find information, and useful content. If your website took the summer off to relax, it’s time to put it back to work.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Web Accessibility Can Boost Your SEO

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/6/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In case having a website that’s accessible to all users wasn’t enough incentive on its own, here’s another reason- it will help boost your SEO rankings. Yeah, true story. On the surface it may not seem like the two are connected, but behind the subtle scenes of your website’s code, proper accessibility practices are providing a major boost to your SEO. What’s that idiom about birds and stones? 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792122860:\n\n\n\n\n\nShow me the money!\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nShow me the money!\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n5/16/12 11:08 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

For most e-commerce websites it is relatively straight forward to put a monetary value on visitors, and therefore, it makes sense to put an effort into search engine optimization (SEO) to get more visitors. If you are running an information only website it might be a lot harder to find out how much a visit is worth.

\n
\n\n

This post is based on a talk I gave at a Danish Conference about making the public sector more efficient by having Citizens use digital solutions more. The talk was about how search engine optimization is a part of the process.

\n

Time is money

\n

You've probably heard this saying more than once in your life. In regards to SEO of public sector and information only websites, time is the currency in which we measure our success. Search engine optimization can be used to free hands from doing menial tasks, which should be automated or done by the users on a self-service website. One of these tasks is to answer questions as to where the answer is or should be available on the website.

\n

Make it easy to find the needle

\n

Searching for answers on a public sector website can often be like looking for a needle in a haystack, mainly because of the vast amounts of information on the sites. Using a search engine to find the information will make the task easier, as long as the information is search engine friendly, like finding the needle will be easier if you are using a magnet, but only if the needle is magnetic.

\n

If users can't find the information they need on the website, they will call or show up in person, taking up valuable employee time. These are avoidable contacts which should have been handled through a much cheaper communications channel.

\n

The fruits are hanging low

\n

Using SEO you can pick some low-hanging fruit, because it can make it easier for your users to find what they are looking for, saving them time and trouble. For you there is a direct win in the avoided contact, but also an indirect win in the fact that your users trust in your website will increase and they will keep using it for future request, which saves you time and money in the long run.

\n

The reason I call it low-hanging fruit is that SEO is relatively cheap and easy to get started with, compared to optimizing complex self-service solutions or business processes. The only thing you need to do is rewrite and add information on the website.

\n

Getting a good start

\n

If you have an information only website, you probably also have a citizens service, customer service or support function which handles the contacts from users, who weren't able to find what they were looking for. These functions are where you'll find the hidden gold. One of the best ways to have an efficient website is to make sure it contains the information your user will expect to find. Every day users tell you contact function exactly what they expect to get from you and this is the information you want on your website. So to get started just ask your contact function what users ask them. Be careful how you ask, because the persons who have the information you need are the same persons you are trying to free up to do other tasks, so sometimes there is a conflict of interests.

\n

When you have found out what information to have and highlight on your website, you just have to get it on there in a search engine friendly format. If you want to dive into the technical areas of search engine optimization there are loads of resources on the web ready to help you. One of these is my previous blog post about 'lending the search engines a helping hand'.

\n

One last but important thing, when you are writing the information please make sure you speak the user's language. It won't help you at all if you are talking about a digging device if your users call it a shovel.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792126540:\n\n\n\n\n\nWeb analytics: gathering qualitative and quantitative data \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nWeb analytics: gathering qualitative and quantitative data \n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/11/12 5:27 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In basic terms, most web analysis systems are based on quantitative data. This quantitative data contributes to general knowledge about the usage of a given website. Everything can then be broken down into numbers and graphs to be interpreted by the person responsible for the optimization of the website.

\n
\n\n
\n

Since the person who interprets the data often has a thorough knowledge of their website, the result will most likely be marked by this. This is natural enough and in most cases it also makes the person interpret the data better. However, in-depth knowledge of the website can also be a hindrance and make you blind to general poor functionality that harms the user experience.

\n

Let the users put it into words

\n

One of the obvious possibilities to get around this interpretation problem is to collect qualitative user data where the user has the opportunity to comment on how they see the user experience.

There are many obvious methods in which you can give users this option. It can be anything from user interviews and sample groups to best user feedback. These methods give the user the ability to verbalize their experience, which can help contribute to an interpretation closer to reality.

When developing new websites, it is a perfectly natural thing to ask users to be involved in user tests or similar. Since you haven't got the quantitative data yet; this is only available from users when your website goes live.

\n

It might be a good idea to pursue the philosophy that lies behind user testing during the design phase. Just because a website "goes live" doesn't mean that it's fully developed. Developing a website is an ongoing process where you constantly have to keep up with how people use it. This knowledge should then be used to constantly strive to improve the user experience.

\n

This exercise is to improve the user experience on your website, and the data you can get, quantitative or qualitative is ultimately beneficial.

\n

Use data for what it is good for

\n

It's important remembering to use the data collected for what it is good for. The quantitative data contributes with large amounts of general knowledge that show a bigger picture of how  mass users use your website. However the qualitative data, that comes directly formulated from the users themselves, contributes with very specific knowledge about specific areas, and information you may never have even thought of.

Each type of data has its own strengths and weaknesses, but the combination of both provides the analysis tool with an extra dimension that can make the interpretation of your data even sharper, and even closer to reality.

The approach to web analytics should be to learn to know your users better, and get as close to reality as possible. In this way you can get in the best position to optimize your website so as thereby to improve the experience users get when they visit. Therefore, it is also important to hear what users have to say in words, and not least allow them to share their experience in an easily accessible manner.

\n

\n \n \n

\n

 

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792126920:\n\n\n\n\n\n5 Ways to Make Your Mobile Website Not Stink\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n5 Ways to Make Your Mobile Website Not Stink\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n9/3/13 2:14 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As smartphone sales continue to overtake the trusty old PC and mobile internet usage grows now is the time to get serious about your mobile platform. With these five simple steps below you’ll quickly be on your way to creating or improving your mobile user experience.

\n
\n
\n

Cut the Crap

\n

Not all website content will be able to effectively fit onto a mobile site, so it’s essential to reduce the amount of content displayed. When deciding what to include, focus on only the most important content and features. This may include information such as contact details, services offered and prices. Additional information such as customer testimonials may be nice to include but isn’t absolutely necessary. Mobile websites should be simple to read and easy to navigate. Remember when it comes to your mobile site less will always be more.

\n

Stay Single

\n

Normal sized web pages overwhelmingly do not suit mobile platforms. When they load, the page ends up being so small that text is unreadable, and forces the user to zoom in to read content. Not only does this add another step to the user journey but it also makes for a navigation nightmare – especially with certain types of phones. Instead, mobile websites should employ the use of single column pages that take up the entire width of the screen. Then depending on how much content you include, make sure that content loads downwards rather than across, as this will make scrolling easier.

\n

Reduce Requirements

\n

Mobile phones have come a long way since the brick handset most of us first had, yet entering large blocks of text using mobile keyboards still remains difficult. While physical QWERTY keyboards tend to be the easiest to use, followed by touchscreen QWERTY keyboards, and then the traditional 12 button physical 12 alphanumeric keypads, all have limitations. Users are much more likely to make mistakes when using mobile keyboards, and are therefore significantly slower - all of which can ruin the user experience. Instead, text entry requirements should be reduced. This can be done a variety of ways, such as offering users the opportunity to use stored details or asking users to enter a pin instead of a password.

\n

Use a Smart Touch

\n

In many countries including the US and the UK, smartphones account for the majority of mobile usage, so it’s essential that your mobile website is optimized for them. Smartphone screens will vary, and may be touch or have more traditional trackball, joystick or directional keys. Your design should be suited to both. The most common navigation difficulty for those using smartphones to surf the web is clicking on the often-small text links accurately. Our fingers tend to fail us, and when links are close together it’s easy to tap the wrong one. Avoid using links for important calls to action, and instead consider using design calls such as thick rows that span the width of the screen or large square boxes that can be easily tapped.

\n

Automate the Advantage  

\n

While desktops and laptops may be easier for web browsing, many smartphones do have advantages over their full-sized cousins – mainly their inbuilt functionality that allows users to bypass manual steps. To ensure your mobile website utilizes these inbuilt functionalities consider the following options:

\n
    \n
  • Allow users to automatically ring a number when they tap or click a phone number.
    • \n
  • Give users the option to select an address and have it automatically open on their mobile phone’s map app.
    • \n
  • Utilize inbuilt GPS systems to help users easily find the things they want nearby.
    • \n
\n

For many more tips on how to improve your website and increase accessibility check out our previous blog post ‘13 Tips to Improve Your Website for Mobile Users and Disabled Users at the Same Time’.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Recent Posts

\n

Get a head start by quality assuring your development site

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n12/19/12 2:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many of our customers launched new websites in 2012, and took advantage of running our Quality Assurance and Accessibility checks on the development website. Finding and fixing errors on their website prior to launching is helpful in it's own right, but allowing the web developers early access to the tools has proven to be invaluable.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

User Feedback - Building a closer relationship with your users

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n6/27/12 10:41 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Communicating with your users online often comes in the form of one way communication. This makes it hard for you to gain insight into what users actually think about your website. In this blog details how user feedback helps build a closer relationship with users, based on a case study of a municipal website in Denmark the Siteimprove has carried out since December 2011.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Corporate Responsibility at Siteimprove

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n4/25/12 11:21 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

At Siteimprove we work with Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) as an essential part of the growth we experience in our three main markets in the UK, USA and in Denmark. A lot of initiatives have already been introduced, for instance we work hard to contribute to a higher degree of Web Accessibility on public and private websites. We wish to minimize our carbon footprint and offer our employees a sound and exciting working environment, in order to encourage employees to create new and even better Web Governance solutions for our customers.

\n
\n

Topics:\nResponsibility\n

\nGive your website a summer spring-cleaning\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n6/24/13 2:25 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

While most of us would probably prefer to use our summer time enjoying the weather, it can be the ideal opportunity to give our websites ...

\n
\n\n
\n

While most of us would probably prefer to use our summer time enjoying the weather, it can be the ideal opportunity to give our websites some much needed dusting. This is especially true for those who work in the education industry or who tend to experience a slowing in business.

\n

With this in mind, we've put together five easy ways to clean up your website:

\n

1. Remove old images

\n

While it’s cozy to have images on your website, especially your homepage, it is important to keep them updated, just as you would your content. Now is the time to remove all those old and perhaps outdated pictures, and instead spend some time in taking or uploading new ones that are more reflective of the coming season. Additionally old images can make your website appear like you’re on vacation, which could send potential customers elsewhere.

\n

2. Invigorate your content

\n

A lighter workload can provide a great time to go through your website and evaluate all your content. Get rid of all misspellings, and outdated information, as begin focusing on refreshing content. This period is ideal for reviewing your website’s content and checking to see whether it is still relevant. By spring-cleaning your content, it can also provide you with new ideas for fresh content to pursue.

\n

3. Check your links

\n

It is also a good idea to take this time to make sure that all your links still work as intended. There is nothing more annoying for your website users than being sent to the black hole that is a 404 page. While this task can be a tad mind numbing, there are tools available that can greatly assist. Also, consider doing some external searching to check for sites that mention your company or web address but don’t actually link back to you. By rectifying this issue you’re not only making it easier for prospects to find you, but it also assist with your SEO efforts.  

\n

4. Review your site stats

\n

The summer time is also perfect for reviewing the information gathered by your analytics program. With these statistics, you should be able to figure out what content has been most successful so far this year, as well as give you general indicators of what kind of things your website users are searching for. Bounce rates can also be useful in helping you to ensure that your website efforts for the remainder of 2013 are as targeted and effective as possible.   

\n

5. Restructure, reformat, restyle

\n

A complete website redesign may not be necessary but these quieter months can be used to take a critical look at the design and layout of your site. Is it professional looking enough, can users easily navigate it, is in keeping with your style guidelines? These are just a few of the basic things that can start thinking about. A good tip can be to ask someone with fresh eyes what they think of your site.

So while it may seem easier to kick back and work on your tan this summer, remember that giving your website a ‘summer’ clean may just give you the competitive edge you need to stay ahead for the rest of 2013.

\n
\n
\n

\n

\nThe Challenge of Maintaining Consistent Website Content\n

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/30/14 11:13 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n\n

Updating your website with new content is essential for increasing search traffic, but it can also create content management headaches as your site grows and your content strategy evolves.

\n\n

In the past we took a look at the Dollars and Cents of Web Governance which highlighted some pretty alarming statistics about the impact that inconsistent and/or error filled content can have on an organization’s bottom line. In this post, and the subsequent webinar, we are going to go beyond general errors like broken links and misspellings to spend some time looking at why organizations struggle so much in keeping their website content free of mistakes that are more unique to them, such as violations of a Style Guide or content that is missing but legally required.

\n

The web is big, visible, easy to edit and hard to manage

\n

Despite the importance of keeping clean web pages, most organizations have a web presence far too large to be managed by their marketing staff. Siteimprove’s 1,865 customers have an average of 4.4 different websites per organization, with a total of 5,975 pages.

\n

If your organization has 10 people strictly devoted to content creation and content strategy, they would have to look after 598 pages on a routine basis along with all their other responsibilities. That is simply not feasible.

\n

If no one were looking at that content it would not be such a big deal, but according to our data, large organizations have incredibly visible content. On average, we see nearly 235,000 page views per year across our customer base. That means that each individual page is seen an average of 39 times every year. According to a study conducted by TowerGroup Estimates, the average transactional cost of online banking was just $0.20, while the average phone call cost $2.40. Think about how much your business could save when employing effective web content to assist customers and clients.

\n

Think about how many people you have updating your website content and how often those updates occur. The number of people editing your website content will vary depending on your industry, but many of you are updating content in some way on a daily basis. If you are a government or educational institution, it may range from 1 to over 100. For businesses, it is more likely to be between 1 and 15 editors.

\n

This can lead to trouble

\n

This truly poses a challenge to website content management, and publishing consistent, compliant content across all pages of an organization’s web presence. Here are a few examples of issues that can creep up:

\n
    \n
  •          We just updated our tagline, is the new one on all our pages?
    • \n
  •          We just changed location, do we have the right contact information everywhere?
    • \n
  •          We prefer "healthcare" over "health care", are all our editors following this guideline?
    • \n
  •          We are required to have a link to our Privacy Policy on every page, is it there?
    • \n
\n

There is a solution

\n

In the upcoming Siteimprove webinar focusing on content consistency, we will further explore specific website content strategy issues that can harm your organization and walk through a four step process to help you mitigate your risk:

\n
    \n
  1.        Have a Style Guide
    2. \n
  2.        Document policies for legally required content
    3. \n
  3.        Ensure everyone knows their role
    4. \n
  4.        Communicate and then over communicate
    5. \n
  5.        Monitor all your content routinely
    6. \n
\n

Your web presence is big, visible, easy to edit and hard to manage. With a little work you can tackle this problem head-on and have the peace of mind that your organization is putting forward a consistent message while avoiding issues due to missing or incompliant content.

\n

\n \n \n  

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

A New Web Governance Roadmap

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/27/13 4:46 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by Shane Diffily. The value of Web Governance is that it can deliver a minimum level of quality for both operations, and online experience. Get it right and you'll have happy users and happy staff. But no online management system ever emerges fully formed. Development, evolution and sometimes revolution are all features of a maturing Web Team. Having worked with dozens of organizations, I now visualize progress in Web Governance as a journey made up of three phases. Use the 'Web Governance Roadmap' described here to work out the distance you have covered on this journey - and what remains to be done.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

\n11/12/13 10:58 AM\n

    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Last Wednesday, November 6th, 2013, Siteimprove was honored to be able to compete in the annual J.Boye conference ‘Web Idol’ competition. Held in Aarhus, Denmark, the conference is a series of international events that aim to bring web practitioners together in an informative environment that fosters relationships and encourages knowledge sharing.

\n
\nRead More\n

A Web Governance Framework That Works

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n10/24/13 4:43 AM\n

    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

The first step in changing Web Governance is often the hardest. There is ample evidence that issues with politics in many organizations have resulted in Governance systems that are extremely resistant to reform. Nevertheless, change must happen eventually. The framework outlined below provides a starting point for this conversation.

\n
\n
