5 Steps to Ensure PDF Documents are Accessible for Everyone

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/15/13 3:49 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by David Herr. PDF content on the web continues to grow each year, despite the issues of ensuring the content is accessible to everyone. It is possible to create completely accessible PDF documents that contain all the rich content and offer the many benefits that PDF files provide. But until recently there have not been good solutions. Manually tagging PDF documents using Adobe® Acrobat Professional is not an easy process and is very prone to errors. Today I will discuss the basic requirements to ensure a PDF document is accessible and can be read using screen reader technology such as JAWS® or NVDA.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n

What's up with 'not provided'?

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 3:18 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In 2011, Google began to hide keyword data for encrypted searches, and this only applied to users who were logged into Google. They have now announced however that this will apply to all users and as such will have a significant impact. Up until now, we have been able to provide excellent insight into what keywords our customers’ users used in search engines but in the next couple of months virtually all keyword data from Google will disappear.

\n
\nRead More\n

Today, 1 October 2013, SaaS company Siteimprove celebrate 10 years of success since first opening in 2003. Having started from humble entrepreneurship roots, Siteimprove has grown exponentially to become a truly successful global company with more than 80 employees, with offices in five countries and customers in 11 countries.

The Eight Deadly Web Analytic Sins

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n8/27/13 3:20 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With budgets continuing to tighten, and workloads increasing, analytics has become a must-have in every professional marketer’s toolbox. However, for many it is still difficult to distinguish between reliable data and valid data. The difference is essentially the way in which the analytics data is set up and subsequently interpreted. In the following eight points we will show how you can end up with data that looks reliable but that is unfortunately not valid by committing a few simple sins.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792127920:\n\n\n\n\n\n5 Steps to Ensure PDF Documents are Accessible for Everyone \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n5 Steps to Ensure PDF Documents are Accessible for Everyone \n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/15/13 3:49 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by David Herr. PDF content on the web continues to grow each year, despite the issues of ensuring the content is accessible to everyone. It is possible to create completely accessible PDF documents that contain all the rich content and offer the many benefits that PDF files provide. But until recently there have not been good solutions. Manually tagging PDF documents using Adobe® Acrobat Professional is not an easy process and is very prone to errors. Today I will discuss the basic requirements to ensure a PDF document is accessible and can be read using screen reader technology such as JAWS® or NVDA.

\n
\n
\n

So what is required to ensure a PDF document is accessible? First of all, a brief history on PDFs: The original specification for PDF was to create a “digital paper” or an exact image of the document so that it could be printed or viewed but not easily altered. This is the “physical view” that is printed and viewed when you open a PDF file in Adobe Reader. In 2003, Adobe introduced “structure” to PDF documents with Adobe Acrobat 6.0 (PDF version 1.5) thus providing the infrastructure necessary for assistive technology devices, such as screen readers, to read PDF documents.

\n

So how do you create an accessible PDF document from an ordinary PDF document?

\n
    \n
  1. Tag the PDF document using Adobe Acrobat Professional. Tagging the document adds structure to the document as shown in the Tag Panel (Tags are used by assistive technology devices) and the Content Panel (which is used by Acrobat’s Reflow feature). You do this by going into the Tools and Accessibility Tabs in Acrobat and select “add tags to document.”

    2. \n
  2. Fix the Content order. This ensures that the order of the content is arranged so it reads in the same order as a person with sight would read it. This is also sometimes referred to as the reading order.

    3. \n
  3. Correct the Tags. Except in very simple documents, the tag structure created by Adobe should only be used as the starting point. Content will be tagged incorrectly, for example a list item might be labeled as a paragraph. Alt-text descriptions need to be added to image tags, tables need to have header, row and data cells tagged and other corrections need to be made to ensure that the tag view accurately describes the content in the physical view.

    4. \n
  4. Examine the remaining accessibility checkpoints such as use of color/contrast.

    5. \n
  5. A good final “check” is to listen to the document using a screen reader technology such as JAWS or NVDA. 
    6. \n
\n

In future blogs, I will discuss how there are software tools now available on the market to help to ensure that your existing PDF documents are accessible and to create accessible PDF content directly from Microsoft Office.

\n

About David Herr

\n

Document Accessibility Consultant – NetCentric Technologies

\n

After 25 years of working as an Information Technology Consultant and IT professional working for several non-profit senior living organizations, serving in several leadership roles, David joined the team at NetCentric Technologies in 2012. His experience working in large IT organizations allows him to understand the problems and helps him to design solutions to meet the needs of his clients. As a document accessibility consultant, David looks to first understand the client’s requirements and then develop a solution that will meet all their needs. He is a strategic thinker and looks at the big picture, rather than just the immediate solution.

\n

In his current role at NetCentric, David is developing with his clients, the processes necessary to address the entire scope of document accessibility, including discovery, remediation and the creation of accessible content. He is also working with CMS providers to develop methods to check documents for accessibility prior to publication.

\n

David has authored several white papers on PDF Accessibility in Higher Education and State Government and is actively speaking at conferences around the country. For more information on David Herr, see his LinkedIn profile at http://www.linkedin.com/in/davidmherr

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792131470:\n\n\n\n\n\nCarefully Selected Content: Website Redesign Tips From a Search Perspective\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nCarefully Selected Content: Website Redesign Tips From a Search Perspective\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n10/3/12 4:05 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

The Siteimprove series on maximizing the potential of a website redesign continues with today's post on the internal search function. We'll take a look at ideas on how your internal search can be used as a helping tool in the general design and testing of your website, as well as guidance on how to best design your search page.

\n
\n\n
\n

Use search statistics to get closer to your user's needs

\n

Your internal search can help you even before you start designing your website. This is the perfect time to take a closer look at what your users want by simply using your internal search statistics.

\n

You can benefit from your internal search terms when you decide about organizing your navigation menus and your website's general structure. Your most popular search terms tell you what your users are most interested in. Bring this information to the forefront of your website during a redesign. Make sure the information is visible on your home page, and use terms that users would use rather than sticking to another term that is often used within your organization.

\n

Use your internal search as a tool for testing migrated content

\n

Make your search solution run in a test environment. That way you can test whether new pages that are being migrated or added are shown correctly in your search results. Ask yourself:

\n
    \n
  • Is the title specific and unique for the page?
    • \n
  • Does the description help users decide which search result to pick?
    • \n
  • Are there any search results that come up in the results twice?   
    • \n
\n

During content migration, check search results every few days using the most popular search terms.

\n

Make sure you also find errors on parts of your website that you have been paying less attention to by searching for placeholder terms that should not be on the final site, such as:

\n
    \n
  • 'Test'
    • \n
  • 'No title'
    • \n
\n

These search terms might lead you to parts of your site that do not follow the general structure of the website.

\n

Designing your search page

\n

The trend in search page design leans towards simplicity. Filtering options, filed specific search boxes, and other extra functionality is only used rarely. My advice is that you only keep the most essential functions, and use the extra space for the search results.

\n

The search results are the main focus of the results page, so enrich these with useful and concise information. You can show photos of employees or contact info directly on the search page. Maybe there is a "buy'" or "download" link that can be displayed directly in the search result?

\n

Which content should your search solution cover?

\n

Ask yourself; which domains, sites and subsites do your organization use? Would any external sites be included in your search? Users are not aware of what and where content is placed on your sites. Let your search include content across domains, so you can maximize the help that is provided directly via your website.

\n

Your search statistics will guide you in finding out whether the content of a specific subsite should be integrated in the main site search or not. If the answers to your user's search queries are on a different domain of a different subsite, then include them in your mail search.

\n

You may also have information on your main domain that are not suitable to be made searchable from your global search function.  For instance, an archive of agendas and minutes is used by a specific user group. Most users have no need to access this information but the users who do may be more open towards using special functions, such as searching for a specific part of the document only or sorting results by date.

\n

When considering which types of pages should be in your main search there are three questions you should ask:

\n
    \n
  1. Do users search for the information on the pages? 
    2. \n
  2. Do the pages have a structure that makes it possible to integrate them well in the search? 
    3. \n
  3. Are the pages being searched for by a specific group of users only?
    4. \n
\n

If you decide to leave a part of your site out of the search and make it searchable in a separate search, remember to set up a quick link in your search that informs users about this. When using a separate search, it makes sense to address the needs of the user group that are especially interested in (e.g. minutes) by using advanced search functions since users with a special interest or knowledge use these options more often.

\n

Your search box should be prominent

\n

The search box should be at least as big as the main menu elements, and should either be placed in the top right area of the page or in the center part of the page. You can find some  inspiration for creating your perfect search box by clicking here.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792139110:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow to Track Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions With Events\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nHow to Track Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions With Events\n

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Website technology has evolved so fast that tracking meaningful interactions can be difficult: White paper downloads, form submissions, and even watching informational videos can all be seen as KPIs and/or MCs, but are often impossible to track with the “out of the box” functionality of most web analytics tools. If you want to track these critical data points, you need to customize your tracking code – a seemingly daunting task.

\n
\n

This is the second post in our series on web analytics for B2B websites, and builds on our previous post on the importance of establishing Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) and Micro Conversions (MCs) to make meaningful improvements to your site. Today we’ll look at how to track those interactions within a web analytics tool with Event Tracking.

\n

If the thought of tracking KPIs and MCs sounds overwhelming, rest assured: all hope is not lost. In many cases all you need is to begin tracking Events.

\n

From a strictly technical standpoint, Events are ways visitors interact with your website without going to another HTML page on your website. For example, watching a video or clicking a link to another website are both instances of events: someone clicked something, and something happened that didn’t involve loading a new page. Setting up all your KPIs as Events can be incredibly useful when it’s time to report your analytical findings to leadership.

\n

Many people are unaware that this functionality is present in any analytics tool worth using. Siteimprove Analytics, Google Analytics, WebTrends, et all have the ability to track Events. Therefore, when evaluating tools for your organization it’s important to ask, “how are Events set up so I can effectively measure success on my website?” There is an opportunity for a whole separate post here on how to decide between free and paid tools, but for the sake of brevity I’ll limit my thoughts on that topic to a few sentences:

\n

Free tools and paid tools both cost money in different ways. If you are willing and able to pay with your time to learn the free tools, then you should use free tools. If you are unwilling and/or unable to pay with your time to learn the free tools then you should purchase a tool. There will always be a certain amount of work involved in effectively analyzing a website, and that time commitment grows if you decide to go the free route.

\n

Once you’ve decided what kind of tool is right for you, it’s time to get Event tracking set up! In most cases Events require a “Category,” “Action,” and “Label” so you can easily distinguish between different Events. It’s up to you (or you and your analytics provider) to determine the appropriate naming conventions for your Events. This is critical, as it will affect how you are able to use the data in your analysis. Due to the importance of this task I would like to look at each item on its own.

\n

Category

\n

The first part in naming an Event is placing it in a category. Video can be a category that encompasses all video on a website. Links can be a category for your Events that happen to be links. Audio can work for podcasts, etc. It’s best not to get too creative with your categories and just stick with common sense. The only reason to get creative is if you need to distinguish some sub-categories in order to better analyze your information.

\n

Here’s a quick example:

\n

Let’s say I’m a manufacturing company that builds different kinds of widgets based on two different types of customers, Mikes and Ikes. I have some PDF documents that outline the specifications of my widgets, and when those documents are downloaded that tells me there is an interest in potentially purchasing my widgets.  If the only category I had was “Documents” then I may need to do some extra analysis every time I needed to recommend website updates to my leadership. What I could do instead is have one category called “Mike Documents” and another called “Ike Documents.” Then I can look at my conversions at a glance based on the type of customer downloading the specs allowing me to determine a course of action with less effort.

\n

If you’re just getting started with this and don’t have access to a consultant, it might be wise to stick to more basic categories. If there is a case to be made for sub-categories, then go for it.

\n

Action

\n

Actions are very self-explanatory. This is the action that a user takes on an Event. For a video it could be “play,” for a link it could be “click,” for a document it could be “download.” We don’t need to get into much detail on these. Just call a spade a spade and you’ll be fine.

\n

Label

\n

The Label element is often the name of the Event being interacted with. The title of an individual document is a good label, the name of a video will work. This is another area that does not require much depth, just common sense. You simply need to be able to recognize individual Events within your categories and the Label is the way to do so.

\n

Once you have settled on the naming conventions for all your Events, you then need to follow the appropriate steps for your Analytics tool of choice in order to track them. If you’re a Siteimprove Analytics customer, that step is to contact our support team, who will guide you through the entire process. Otherwise, consult your tool’s support options and get down to brass tacks.

\n

You will then begin collecting the glorious information on how often people are taking action on your KPIs and MCs. This is progress! It is also just the second step in our journey, and there’s so much more value ahead. In our next installment we’ll take a look at the value of making Campaign Tracking a part of your outbound marketing efforts.

\n

Want more best practices for measuring your website’s success? Check out our report on the eight most deadly web analytics mistakes:

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792139720:\n\n\n\n\n\n Q&A on the Basics of Web Accessibility\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\n Q&A on the Basics of Web Accessibility\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n2/11/14 9:01 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

We get a lot of questions on web accessibility here at Siteimprove, and want to take this opportunity to answer as many of them as we can. This may be more of a review for you seasoned accessibility folks, but there’s a growing demand for this introductory information as more web professionals recognize the importance of accessibility. 

\n

\n
\n

Q: What is Web Accessibility and why is it important to the success of my website?

\n

A: Web accessibility refers to the inclusive practice of making websites usable by people of all abilities and disabilities. When sites are correctly designed, developed and edited, all users can have equal access to information and functionality.

\n

Q: What standards should I use?

\n

A: Depending on your location, there may be various sets of accessibility standards that you will need to follow. Fortunately, the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) has a comprehensive list called the WCAG 2.0 that has been widely adopted, and is the base set of guidelines for most other standards. Although the following list is far from complete, here are a few other sets of standards to look at:

\n
    \n
  • Section 508
    • \n
  • Web Standards for the Government of Canada
    • \n
  • AODA (Ontario)
    • \n
\n

Q: What are the benefits of website accessible coding standards?

\n

A: There may be a few benefits to coding accessibility into your website that you may not have thought much about. These are benefits that go beyond just the minimum of meeting accessibility laws:

\n

Social Responsibility
It’s time to act socially responsible. Accessibility is about allowing people with and without disabilities to have access to the information they want and need. As our population changes, we need to educate the people responsible for generating communication channels to be aware of ALL of our different users.

\n

A Larger Customer Base
With reports of one in five people in the US claiming some sort of disability, 20% of the population is just too large of a group to ignore. If you go the extra steps to accommodate this group, you will be certain of a loyal, (and wealthy) group of customers. 

\n

Efficient Code
Once you’ve developed a clean, accessible code base, you will be amazed at the benefits. Efficient code can help improve:

\n
    \n
  • Website Maintenance
    • \n
  • Device compatibility
    • \n
  • Faster page loading
    • \n
  • Search Engine Optimization (SEO)
    • \n
\n
\n

Q: What are the “Nuts and Bolts” of web accessibility?

\n

A: We receive many accessibility questions that are more technical in nature, because the standards can get pretty complex. Here are a few of the more important coding practices, and even better, some practices that are quite simple to control in your different coding environments. Among those practices are:

\n
    \n
  • Semantic Markup
    • \n
  • Page Titles
    • \n
  • Headings
    • \n
  • Graphics
    • \n
  • Links
    • \n
  • Tables and Forms
    • \n
\n

Addressing these areas adds an immense amount of usability to your overall site, and provides a solid framework to build on.

\n

Q: What is Assistive Technology?

\n

A: When talking about assistive devices to aid visitors with disabilities, the first and sometimes only device that comes to most people’s mind is a screen reader (if you haven’t heard of a screen reader, it’s a tool that reads pages aloud to people with low vision or severe dyslexia). While screen readers are an extremely important assistive device, it’s by no means the only device. Other assistive technologies are used to support a wide range of disabilities. These technologies include:

\n
    \n
  • Screen readers
    • \n
  • Windows and Mac Accessibility features
    • \n
  • Color contrast analyzers
    • \n
  • Toolbars/extensions/plug ins
    • \n
  • Mobile devices
    • \n
\n

When optimizing your website to accommodate users with disabilities, it’s important to understand what kind of issues they may encounter depending on the type of assistive technology they may be using.

\n

Q: How do I get started?

\n

A: We’re offering an on-demand webinar on getting started with a web accessibility plan. We’ll cover all the questions mentioned here in greater detail, and help outline an approach that you can work right into your existing workflows with (hopefully) minimal disruption.

\n

If you’re already doing most of the things you need to, the webinar is still a valuable way to point out a few things to add that will assist with your accessibility goals. We’ll discuss:

\n
    \n
  • Knowing the Rules
    • \n
  • Practical Testing and Training Plans
    • \n
  • Low-hanging Fruit
    • \n
  • High Traffic Pages
    • \n
  • A-level Errors
    • \n
  • Report and Track Progress
    • \n
\n

  \n \n \n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792139870:\n\n\n\n\n\nA New Web Governance Roadmap\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nA New Web Governance Roadmap\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/27/13 4:46 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by Shane Diffily. The value of Web Governance is that it can deliver a minimum level of quality for both operations, and online experience. Get it right and you'll have happy users and happy staff. But no online management system ever emerges fully formed. Development, evolution and sometimes revolution are all features of a maturing Web Team. Having worked with dozens of organizations, I now visualize progress in Web Governance as a journey made up of three phases. Use the 'Web Governance Roadmap' described here to work out the distance you have covered on this journey - and what remains to be done.

\n
\n\n
\n

The value of good Web Governance is that it can deliver a minimum level of quality for both operations and online experience.

\n

But there's something to remember.

\n

Without a higher purpose, even the best governance system is like a Porsche stuck in neutral. A beautiful machine, but ultimately pointless.

\n

As such, we must never forget that Web Governance is not an end in itself. It is a means to an end.

\n

The real point is that it gives you the stability you need to focus on more important things - like your online goals.

\n

Web Governance is a journey

\n

No online management system ever emerges fully formed and perfect. Development, evolution and sometimes revolution are all features of a maturing Web Team.

\n

Having worked with dozens of organizations in many industries, I now visualize progress in Web Governance as a journey made up of three phases (as shown below).

\n

These phases reflect how an organization - and its incumbent web manager - advance towards operational stability.

\n


\n
\n

PHASE 1: Discover

\n

At Phase 1, an organization discovers the topic of Web Governance for the first time. The focus here is on learning what online management is all about and seeing how to use these ideas to put order on complexity.

\n

PHASE 2: Organize

\n

By this stage, the organization finally 'gets' Web Governance and is ready to commit to doing it right. The Web Manager is given the go-ahead to create a proper system of control, with the manpower, skills, tools, and other things needed to build operational stability.

\n

PHASE 3: Optimize

\n

You are now in the happy position of having a governance system that is broadly right. That is, you have the right people in the right roles with the right tools and the right budget, etc, with few distractions like role conflict or missing leadership.

\n

In addition, because there are so few distractions, you are able to spend time optimizing your already functional governance to make it even better, e.g. by scrutinizing the new Analytics of Web Governance I have written about before.

\n

PHASE 2+: Re-Organize

\n

It's worth noting that from time to time, even firms with stable governance may go through periods of turmoil that require online management to be reorganized, e.g. as the result of a merger, a major strategy change, etc.

\n
\n

A new roadmap for Web Governance

\n

Different industries progress at different rates along this journey.

\n

Even within industries, a wide range of governance maturity may be exhibited. Some are leaders and others followers.

\n
\n

Q. Who is best globally at Web Governance?

\n

A. It's very hard to say. Few organizations share insight about their online management. However, the Government Digital Services (GDS) team in the UK is doing some amazing work and frequently publishes about it.

\n
\n

Issues such as politics, culture, and leadership often influence how quickly an organization makes progress.

\n

To see where your Web Team sits on this journey, compare yourself against the Web Governance Roadmap below.

\n

Which persona best reflects your current experience?

\n

\n
\n

FREE download. Get the Web Governance Roadmap in PDF format.
Click to download the Web Governance Roadmap now (1.2MB)

\n
\n






\n
\n

FREE download. Get the Web Governance Roadmap in PDF format.
Click to download the Web Governance Roadmap now (1.2MB)

\n
\n

Where should I be?

\n

There is no hard and fast rule as to where you should be on this journey.

\n

That said, if you manage a web presence that is core to overall strategy and are in a mid-large scale organization, I recommend that you get to Stage 2 pretty soon.

\n

The demands of online are now so onerous and complex that flapping around the edges of Web Governance is no longer good enough. It's time to do it right.

\n

A Web Team that must endure ill-defined roles, out-of-date procedures and leadership neglect will eventually buckle under the strain. Executives who ignore this reality are putting their entire online investment at risk.

\n

Furthermore, not only is Web Governance important for risk avoidance, but is also emerging as a key element of competitive advantage.

\n

Just as we have seen other specialisms of online (such as usability, content, analytics, etc.) become important as differentiators - so too is Web Governance.

\n

An organization with a governance system that is fine-tuned for stability (zero online errors, zero operational issues) will be far more agile than its peers and able to react to opportunity faster. This is particularly important in sectors where other core disciplines have already been mastered.

\n

Snake oil?

\n

If you agree these are good reasons to get serious about online management, you're not alone. Lots of people are currently talking about Web Governance.

\n

As Gartner would have it, we are in a bit of a Hype Cycle at the moment.

\n

As a relatively new concept, lots of amazing benefits are being promised for Web Governance - some of which will certainly be delivered. But we must remain wary of the 'peak of inflated expectations' and keep our feet on the ground.

\n

There will be no quick fixes and no magic solutions.

\n

Online stability will only emerge as the result of a steady journey - one that builds a configuration of governance that is appropriate to the scale of your digital operations.

\n
\n

FREE download. Get the Web Governance Roadmap in PDF format.
Click to download the Web Governance Roadmap now (1.2MB)

\n
\n
\n

About Shane Diffily

\n

Shane has more than 14 years' experience in web governance, website management and operations. Until recently he worked as a Senior Analyst with a leading User Experience design firm, iQ Content. He now works as an independent consultant specializing in Web Governance, and is an official Siteimprove Partner.

\n

Read more from Shane

\n

Shane is a prolific author and thought leader. Check out some of his other articles here:

\nTop-Down, Bottom-up: 2 Approaches to Better Web Governance at Your University\n

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\nFind me on:\n
\nTwitter \n
\n
\n

\n

\n4/10/14 1:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

I have heard it said that if a university was a country, it would last about a week before breaking apart in civil war. At first brush it sounded ridiculous, but now I think it actually makes a good bit of sense.

\n
\n

Think about it – a university:

\n
    \n
  • Has a large population.
    • \n
  • Is highly diverse.
    • \n
  • Is geographically distributed.
    • \n
  • Has lots of stakeholders and specialist interest groups.
    • \n
\n

So, short of calling out the troops, what can you do to get everyone acting in a unified way online?

\n

Enter ‘Web Governance’

\n

The purpose of Web Governance is to create stability in online operations.

\n

In an ideal system, all issues of ownership, authority, responsibility and resourcing are put to bed so you can focus your energies on pursuing online goals.

\n

For a small organization, this is usually quite manageable. All you need to keep the show on the road are a few informal procedures and some basic freeware tools.

\n

However, this type of informality does not scale well.

\n

For example, if the governance sophistication of a large university fails to keep pace with its online ambitions, things fall apart.

\n
    \n
  • In the absence of agreed-upon rules, solo-runs become common as individual colleges do their own thing, resulting in a wide diversity of technology and design.
    • \n
  • In the absence of skilled support, great disparities in the quality of experience emerge, as some sites are well maintained and others are ignored.
    • \n
\n
    \n
  • In the absence of necessary tools, no one can track what is happening online, exposing you to reputational risk.
    • \n
\n

There is a way out!

\n

The answer lies in recognizing that professionalism in Web Governance must keep pace with online ambition. In the first instance, this means adopting a more sophisticated top-down model of online management. Second, it means investing in better bottom-up supports for staff, to help them maintain quality.

\n

Let’s examine both of these approaches in more detail.

\n

Impose order from the top down

\n

A key problem on many large sites is that the complexity of operations overtakes the ability of a Web Manager to make sense of it. There are simply too many things going on.

\n

Adding to this, unlike other aspects of management (HR, finance, marketing, etc.), there is as yet little understanding of what exactly Web Governance is about.

\n

An essential first step, then, is to re-impose order on operations using a structured governance framework.

\n

Indeed, this approach can work particularly well in institutions of higher learning.

\n

Academics are used to dealing in frameworks and models, whether for physics, economics or politics. Explaining the needs and purpose of Web Governance in a similar way means you’re already speaking a language they understand.

\n

The new Framework of Web Governance describes all the elements needed to manage an online presence.

\n

The main benefit of this framework is that it reasserts order over complexity, and reveals interconnections that were once obscure by grouping similar elements together.

\n

Its second benefit is simplicity.

\n

The framework shows how everything to do with online management can be described in terms of just 3 elements. These are:

\n
    \n
  • Activity: This describes everything you must do to manage a website, no matter how big or small your site is.
    • \n
  • Resource: This describes everything you must invest in to make governance happen, e.g. people, tools, etc.
    • \n
  • Scale: This describes how to balance the Activities & Resources in a configuration of governance that works.
    • \n
\n

The simplicity of this framework makes it very effective as a communications tool when explaining what Web Governance is about to senior executives.

\n

\n

Read a complete introduction to the New Framework of Web Governance.

\n

It is also useful for contextualizing the roles & responsibilities of everyone involved in operations. This includes the many non-web staff typically involved in day-to-day maintenance, e.g. content publishers.

\n

This brings us to our second approach for improving Web Governance: bottom-up.

\n

Invest from the bottom up

\n

The clearest trend in Web Governance in recent years has been towards the centralization of digital activity.

\n

As noted by leading expert at Cap Gemini, Didier Bonnet: “Older Silo based operations … are coming under increasing pressure to change.”

\n

Several examples of this tendency can be seen within higher education, such as at RMIT in Australia and Harvard University, as well as in other sectors, such as government.

\n

The defining feature of this model is that nothing significant happens online without the say of the central digital unit.

\n

Well, almost nothing.

\n

Inevitably, there are instances where doing things centrally can actually inhibit progress, rather than assist it.

\n

The principle of subsidiarity states that in a highly distributed organization some activities should continue to be exercised at a local level. The challenge is allowing this to occur while still maintaining standards.

\n

This is where your new system of Web Governance must be backed-up by the supports staff need to do their jobs, e.g. online tools, process documentation, etc.

\n

In the last Siteimprove webinar, Ahava Leibtag of Aha Media Group referred to several items commonly used by content producers. The documentation and tools she described can have great utility in making subsidiarity work.

\n

The good news is that these aids can be extended far beyond publishing into other tasks of governance, e.g. quality assurance, performance monitoring, user engagement and more.

\n

Indeed, I recommend that supports of this type be packaged together into a Web Governance Toolkit for distribution among staff.

\n

\n

For example, such a toolkit may include:

\n
    \n
  • A step-by-step guide to creating a new website.
    • \n
  • A step-by-step guide to maintaining a website.
    • \n
  • A series of documented personas.
    • \n
  • An online style guide.
    • \n
  • A series of approved KPIs.
    • \n
  • Online access to approved tools, including CMS, Analytics, QA, Social monitoring, etc.
    • \n
\n

Visit diffily.com to download free samples from a Web Governance Toolkit.

\n

This material may be collected into printed ‘packs’ and presented to staff, perhaps at the start of a major development project or as a new site goes live. This means everyone has everything they need from the word go.

\n

When done well, a toolkit can endow your Web Team with enhanced credibility and reinforce your role as a guiding authority for online.

\n

Wait, there’s more

\n

So, we see that despite the challenges of Web Governance, there are ways to deal with it.

\n

Indeed, given the scale of the challenges, it is not surprising that some of the best solutions to online management arise within Higher Education.

\n

To learn more, be sure to tune in to my upcoming webinar on April 9th, “Top Down, Bottom Up: Two Approaches to Better Web Governance in Your University.”

\n

Shane has more than 14 years’ experience in Web Governance & online operations. As author of the first practical guide to Web Governance (“The Website Manager’s Handbook”), Shane has also been published by A List Apart, Smartinsights & Forrester Research. For lots of FREE Web Governance downloads, visit www.diffily.com.

\n

\n \n \n

13 Tips to Improve Your Website for Mobile Users and Disabled Users at the Same Time

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n10/17/12 3:46 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Smart phone sales are exploding, and the desire to make websites accessible to all users on mobile platforms is also increasing. I’m going to give you some tips on how to create accessible web content in the best way.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Going for gold; developing an elite website

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n9/26/12 4:08 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Like an athlete at the Olympics, your website should be fit and free from injury. This way you can achieve the best performance and value from your website every day.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Just like sports, websites should be accessible to everyone

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n9/5/12 3:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With the Paralympics underway, world coverage of the 2nd biggest multinational event has highlighted how sports should be enjoyed by everyone, regardless of their disability, but what about the accessibility of websites?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

New website – Think web accessibility from day 1

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n8/29/12 4:40 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

If you are about to redesign your website, now is a good time to focus on getting a website that can be used by as many people as possible. Here are some tips on when and how to make requirements and focus on accessibility throughout the process.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Avoid These Common Accessibility Mistakes

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n8/8/12 4:47 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Find out if you use alternative texts, headings and forms correctly and if you in general help people with disabilities and dyslexia etc. on your website

\n

In this blog, we'll cover several common misunderstandings in connection with accessibility problems on websites. Find out whether your website is doing it right or wrong.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n

Want to understand accessibility? Participate!

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n7/4/12 10:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Why is it important to be able to use a webpage without using a computer mouse? How does it work when a web page text is enlarged? How does a screen reader interpret a web page? Get the answers to these questions and learn why and to whom this is important.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 ways to improve your accessibility right now

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/9/12 11:11 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It can be difficult to know where to start if you have not implemented web accessibility before. Where do you begin and how do you finish? Some areas require time and a targeted effort whilst there are some ways in which you can improve your website accessibility right away, and at the same time conform with 3 important criteria in WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines).

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The added bonus of ensuring web accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/2/12 11:19 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you looking to attract more visitors and retain happier users of your website? If so, then read on! By conforming with a number of accessibility criteria you can not only optimize the accessibility of your website, but also ensure good usability and increased visibility in search engines (SEO).

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why do I suddenly have more accessibility issues?

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n4/18/12 11:28 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Web professionals looking to improve their website accessibility using Siteimprove tools are finding that they have more issues in Quality Assurance, than they had in the former SiteCheck, but they are unsure of why.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What is Web Accessibility?

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n3/21/12 11:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

The term “Accessibility” is often used broadly, but there is a clear definition of what we mean: ensuring that as many users as possible can navigate and comprehend a website.

\n
\n

Being in the accessibility industry, I meet many web professionals with differing thoughts on what web accessibility is. Some think that it's all about uptime and response time (Availability), others say usability, and some say search engine optimization (SEO) or "find-ability." Some believe that accessibility means that everything on your website can be read aloud in an automated way. I think you get the idea.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

How Will the Net Neutrality Rulings Impact Consumers and Businesses?

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/9/14 9:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The debate over Net Neutrality has intensified once again and will likely continue to do so as Internet Service Providers like Comcast and Verizon push for a Federal Communications Commission (FCC) ruling in their favor on May 20, 2014. The outcome of this debate could have drastic impacts on the way consumers and businesses use the Internet as a communication and information sharing platform, so make sure you know what it could mean for you and your company.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/6/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We’ve all been there: deadlines are looming and there just aren’t enough hours in the day to meet them all. Website management teams are often too busy putting out fires and treading water to look for smarter ways to work, so we’ve taken it upon ourselves to do the research for you. Here are 4 great ways that you can save yourself time on things you already do.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n

Updating your website with new content is essential for increasing search traffic, but it can also create content management headaches as your site grows and your content strategy evolves.

\n
\nRead More\n

    \n

\n\n\n\n
\n

In order to fully understand the success of your digital marketing efforts you need the complete picture. In this post we will review a key component to capturing information you may be missing, how to implement that process in your organization and provide some guidance on how to add some serious value when you are armed with a more complete data set.

A Look at Assistive Technology

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/15/14 10:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Assistive technologies are tools and methods used to make web information available to people with and without disabilities. With the leaps and bounds in technology the last few years, you may not be aware of all of the different kinds of Assistive Technology available.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nAssistive Technologies\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Top-Down, Bottom-up: 2 Approaches to Better Web Governance at Your University

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\n

\n4/10/14 1:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

I have heard it said that if a university was a country, it would last about a week before breaking apart in civil war. At first brush it sounded ridiculous, but now I think it actually makes a good bit of sense.

\n
\n

Think about it – a university:

\n
    \n
  • Has a large population.
    • \n
  • Is highly diverse.
    • \n
  • Is geographically distributed.
    • \n
  • Has lots of stakeholders and specialist interest groups.
    • \n
\n

So, short of calling out the troops, what can you do to get everyone acting in a unified way online?

\n
\nRead More\n
\n
\n
\n

Say goodbye to inaccessible PDFs on your website

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

”We can’t upload PDFs to our website because PDFs are not accessible“ and “We have to provide an accessible version of our PDFs since it is not possible to make PDFs accessible“ are both common dilemmas experienced among web teams. Perhaps these are sentences you’ve heard or even used yourself?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Stop Putting Out Fires and be Proactive With Your Website

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:24 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Everyone knows reactive marketing is ineffective, but far too many marketers are buried deep under a pile of emergencies to even think about strategic planning. What do you do when your boss comes to your desk every day to light your hair on fire with another emergency?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why Do My Documents Need To Be Accessible?

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Admit it: “PDFs” aren’t usually the first thing that come to mind when you think about website accessibility. They probably should be. PDFs are nearly ubiquitous as a “final” document type on the web, and hosted PDFs are often the only location certain content is made available – especially for educators, the healthcare industry, and government offices. When they aren’t accessible, that information simply isn’t available to users with disabilities.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Track Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions With Events

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website technology has evolved so fast that tracking meaningful interactions can be difficult: White paper downloads, form submissions, and even watching informational videos can all be seen as KPIs and/or MCs, but are often impossible to track with the “out of the box” functionality of most web analytics tools. If you want to track these critical data points, you need to customize your tracking code – a seemingly daunting task.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

As smartphone sales continue to overtake the trusty old PC and mobile internet usage grows now is the time to get serious about your mobile platform. With these five simple steps below you’ll quickly be on your way to creating or improving your mobile user experience.

The Eight Deadly Web Analytic Sins

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n8/27/13 3:20 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With budgets continuing to tighten, and workloads increasing, analytics has become a must-have in every professional marketer’s toolbox. However, for many it is still difficult to distinguish between reliable data and valid data. The difference is essentially the way in which the analytics data is set up and subsequently interpreted. In the following eight points we will show how you can end up with data that looks reliable but that is unfortunately not valid by committing a few simple sins.

\n
\nRead More\n

It’s that time of the year again: Students are lining up to buy textbooks and signing up for classes. BUT WAIT! You have a million back-to-school tasks to complete AND there is a line of students with accessibility requests at your door. Unsure of where to start? Keep calm and accessibility on! We’ll give you five critical places to focus your accessibility efforts first.

Rand Fishkin of Moz addressed the argument brewing in the broader world of Search Engine Optimization strategy: Link Building vs. Content Marketing. While this discussion has flown beneath the radar for most legal marketers, it is clear which side is best for today’s corporate law firm: Content Marketing.

  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Despite the web having been around for over two decades design mistakes are still increasingly prevalent. Below we list five simple, but common, mistakes to avoid when designing a website.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

The Hierarchy of Content Needs: A New Model for Creating and Assessing Content

\n

\nPosted by\nHilary Marsh\n

\n

\n7/9/13 10:53 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by Hilary Marsh Psychologist Abraham Maslow developed a theory of human motivation that he called the hierarchy of needs. As explained in the Economist, “Needs in the lower categories have to be satisfied before needs in the higher ones can act as motivators. Thus a violinist who is starving cannot be motivated to play Mozart, and a shop worker without a lunch break is less productive in the afternoon than one who has had a break.”

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Putting a Face on Accessibility Part II

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n7/1/13 10:21 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Professor Chris Olson has had a really busy year. Chris recently bought and moved into a house. Like many home purchases, there was a bit of remodeling that took place before the move to make the space more usable. Chris will be sharing that new home with his fiancé Cindy. Chris and Cindy were engaged on New Year’s Eve. Chris has been teaching graduate and undergraduate level computer and web programming classes for the past seven years. In March 2013, he successfully defended his doctoral dissertation, “Awareness of Accessibility in Computer-based Instructional Materials and Faculty Demographics in South Dakota Public Universities.”

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

Six Common Misunderstandings About Your CMS

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n6/20/13 2:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

When speaking about web governance (diagnosis, compliance and maintenance) of website quality assurance and accessibility, the common response is, our Content Management System (CMS) has a solution for this. However, this is the common misunderstanding.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

CONFAB 2013 Minneapolis Roundup

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n6/12/13 2:33 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Last week the lovely Kelsey and Dave from our US office were lucky enough to attend the 2013 CONFAB Minneapolis conference. With so much packed into three days (and apparently some great food) they were kind enough to attend a plethora of talks, and take notes for those who were unable to attend. Below you’ll find five round-ups from some of the main Content Gurus were presented throughout the event – Enjoy!

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n

Get Ready for CONFAB Minneapolis 2013

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n6/3/13 2:45 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many people (ourselves included) are excitedly gearing up for the 2013 CONFAB Minneapolis Conference kicking off today. A great event that spans three days, this year’s conference is completely sold out - but it doesn’t mean those of you who don’t have tickets need to miss out.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n

Kevin’s Top 10 Web Accessibility Tips

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/28/13 3:24 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Web accessibility is a complex issue, and there are many rules and guidelines that you need to be aware of as you work towards providing an accessible solution for your users. One of the most frequent questions we hear is, “where do I start?” Here are 10 items to consider when building accessible websites. Whether you are contributing content to a blog, or managing thousands of pages, these tips should put you on the right path.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Raising Digital Discrimination Awareness

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/21/13 3:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Imagine that you’re suddenly blind, maybe unable to make your body function as it did before, perhaps you can no longer read without difficulty or distinguish between colors, conceivably you may just be getting older… Now try accessing the web.

\n
\n
\n

Many people find it difficult to imagine what accessing the web may be like without the basic physical and cognitive traits we often take for granted. Aimed to get people talking, thinking and learning about the estimated 20% of the population with some kind of a disability, Global Accessibility Awareness Day has again concluded for another year - but not without some important lessons being learned the hard way.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The 'Governance' Component of Content Strategy Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n5/14/13 3:58 AM\n

    \n

\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

According to Google CEO, Eric Schmidt, every two days now we create as much content as we did from the dawn of civilization up until 2003. While this mind numbing figure may scare off those considering how to govern content, the last installment in our content strategy series will show how with a clear plan, and the assistance of some clever tools, navigating this mammoth task doesn't need to take you a millennium.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n

Putting a Face on Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/29/13 10:25 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

All too often we forget to put a face on people with disabilities, instead we lump them into categories.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

The 'Publication' Component of Content Strategy Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n4/22/13 4:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Having your content published was once difficult, yet with the emergence of the new media age entry requirements have almost all but disappeared. Instead, the internet has made it possible for almost everyone to share their content, but this isn’t without risks.

\n
\n
\n

With the increasing digitization of the business world, it has now become essential for organizations to become publishers in order to compete against competitors, and gain attention from their target audiences. Yet haphazard publishing can be dangerous for an organization's reputation, especially if standards of reliability, accountability, accuracy and trust slip.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The 'Creation' Component of Content Strategy Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n4/16/13 4:09 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Previously we introduced the concept of ‘content strategy,’ and explained the three essential components that constitute its lifecycle – creation, publication, and governance. In this blog, will delve deeper into how Siteimprove can assist you during the first component: ‘creation.’

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n

The three components of Content Strategy success

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n4/8/13 2:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n

  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Creating effective website content can be an arduous task, especially when so many factors must be considered: varying role capacities, internal politics, customer expectations etc. However, following a structured strategy can make creating focused content a piece of cake!

\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.
